Besides Han in-migration, there was natural demographic increase among the Hmong. “What had once been a single household with several male members might have grown into several households and several tens of males; what had been one hamlet might have divided into several, and then several tens of hamlets.” 6 When Fenghuang and Qianzhou had been established in 1704, 313 hamlets were counted and brought under control. By the end of the century there were estimated to be about 4,000 Miao hamlets in the three subprefectures (see map, above) with a further 1,070 in Songtao.7 The increase had been made possible by the conversion of forest land to agriculture; by good harvests, as elsewhere in central China in the late-eighteenth century; and by the improvement of Miao agricultural techniques, though not to the Han Chinese level. The result was a kind of demographic crisis with land in increasingly short supply. It was not exactly a subsistence crisis - the harvest of 1794 was a good one, enough in the following spring for rebel hamlets to send out their braves fully supplied - but rather a question of declining standards and open envy of Han prosperity in the valleys their Miao grandparents had tilled.8 Two easily overlooked repercussions of demographic pressure were, ecologically, the diminution of fauna that the frontier people had long hunted with muskets and spears; and, socially, the frustration of the Miao practice of newly-marrieds setting up a separate household,9 which especially affected young unmarried males who would be the main fighters in the Miao forces.' [113]

Intensity of warfare[edit]

♠ Annexation ♣ present ♥ The Qing gradually annexed Hmong lands, particularly fertile agricultural lands. [114] Encroachments on arable Hmong territory and subsequent conflict over land were major factors in the rebellions: 'During the Qing Dynasty the Miao fought three wars against the empire.[11] In 1735 in the southeastern province of Guizhou, the Miao rose up against the government's forced assimilation. Eight counties involving 1,224 villages fought until 1738 when the revolt ended. According to Xiangtan University Professor Wu half the Miao population were affected by the war.'[115] 'During the Qing, uprisings and military encounters escalated. There were major disturbances in western Hunan (1795-1806) and a continuous series of rebellions in Guizhou (1854-1872). Chinese policies toward the Miao shifted among assimilation, containment in "stockaded villages," dispersal, removal, and extermination. The frequent threat of " Miao rebellion" caused considerable anxiety to the state; in actuality, many of these uprisings included Bouyei, Dong, Hui, and other ethnic groups, including Han settlers and demobilized soldiers. At issue were heavy taxation, rising landlordism, rivalries over local resources, and official corruption.' [116] 'During the Ts'ung Cheng reign period /1628/ /the end of the Ming dynasty/, the Miao rebelled, demolishing the guard stations and leveling the border wall. The “Great Wall” to blockade Miao country disappeared. The 7,800 guard troops /shou ping/ in the Miao area of the Ming dynasty were reduced to 1,600 men at the beginning of the Ch'ing dynasty. When the rebellion of Wu San-kwei was pacified and all was peaceful again, there was another reduction of 500 men, leaving 1,100 men. Military strengh was slight and the defense system was relaxed. Further, following the change from native headmen to Chinese officials, and the use of Chinese as the head of every hundred families, intercourse between the Chinese and the Miao was no longer prohibited. In the twenty-ninth year of Ch'ien Lung /i.e. 1764/, in view of the Miao having undergone acculturation for a long time, they were allowed to intermarry with the Chinese. The original idea was to change the Miao by teaching, but with the passing of time evils developed, when rapacious Chinese under the pretext of trade entered the Miao area and seduced crafty Miao to enter into thievery. Unlike soldiers they entered Miao country for personal reasons and mistreated the Miao. The Miao made a pretext of these guest men's exploitations and encroachments on their land and banded together to make trouble, and brought about the great rebellion during the Ch'ien Lung /1736-95/ and Chia Ch'ing /1796-1820/ reign periods. After the rebellion was put down, the Manchu court realized that the time was yet inopportune to change the Miao by teaching, and the blockade policy was once more used. The various hsiens along the Miao border were heavily garrisoned for protection.' [117]

♠ Looting ♣ absent ♥ Violent altercations during the rebellions involved sack and destruction rather than looting alone (see below). But our sources also report feuding among the Hmong themselves and raids involving both Hmong and Yi/Lolos: 'The endemic cultural elements relevant to the uprising can be specified briefly. 1. Affinal connections were strongly emphasized with the help of frequent cross-cousin marriage and the levirate.11 2. After many decades of direct Qing rule, a loose structure of appointed hamlet (zhai ን) heads and baihu ۍ֪ʳ(“hundred-family heads”) had given some definition to what had been an acephalous local society almost untouched by tusi authority centered far to the north. 3. Ecstatic possession was a key means of spiritual contact, and shamans played an important role as ritual leaders at the hamlet level. 4. There was a tradition of a Miao king appearing in times of collective trouble. 5. Organized feuds were an established custom, with a sequence of dispute, violence and negotiated recompense. In such feuds bloodoaths to the local gods, the White Emperor Heavenly Kings, preceded participation in violent raids, and kuanhui ཱིᄎ, a sort of intermittent, multi-hamlet association, helped to resolve them. The revolt’s loose structure and direction reflected these regional cultural practices and beliefs.12 In form it produced no novel organization, as the Taipings would fifty years later, and in spirit it was not a revolutionary attack on local society, at least on its Miao aspects, but a sharpening of its basic cultural and institutional features against the threat of outsiders, or those perceived as outsiders.' [118] 'There were formerly many fortified places called in Chinese chai tzŭ □ where groups of houses were clustered together for protection. This is indicated by the names of places such as Wang Wu Chai □ and by the frequent references to fortified places in the legends. To-day there [Page 23] are none to be found. One explanation given by Ch'uan Miao friends is that the danger of fire was too great so that people no longer built their houses so close together. There are two other possible reasons. One is that the Chinese destroyed the strongholds in war and to prevent future rebellions, and the other is that there is no longer danger of raids and attacks from the Lolos. Chinese histories actually mention the destruction of the strongholds' [119] We are unsure as to how destructive those raids and feuds were or which tactics were commonly used. We have provisionally coded 'absent', but expert feedback is needed on the matter.

♠ Sack ♣ present ♥ Our sources also report feuding among the Hmong themselves and raids involving both Hmong and Yi/Lolos: 'The endemic cultural elements relevant to the uprising can be specified briefly. 1. Affinal connections were strongly emphasized with the help of frequent cross-cousin marriage and the levirate.11 2. After many decades of direct Qing rule, a loose structure of appointed hamlet (zhai ን) heads and baihu ۍ֪ʳ(“hundred-family heads”) had given some definition to what had been an acephalous local society almost untouched by tusi authority centered far to the north. 3. Ecstatic possession was a key means of spiritual contact, and shamans played an important role as ritual leaders at the hamlet level. 4. There was a tradition of a Miao king appearing in times of collective trouble. 5. Organized feuds were an established custom, with a sequence of dispute, violence and negotiated recompense. In such feuds bloodoaths to the local gods, the White Emperor Heavenly Kings, preceded participation in violent raids, and kuanhui ཱིᄎ, a sort of intermittent, multi-hamlet association, helped to resolve them. The revolt’s loose structure and direction reflected these regional cultural practices and beliefs.12 In form it produced no novel organization, as the Taipings would fifty years later, and in spirit it was not a revolutionary attack on local society, at least on its Miao aspects, but a sharpening of its basic cultural and institutional features against the threat of outsiders, or those perceived as outsiders.' [120] 'There were formerly many fortified places called in Chinese chai tzŭ □ where groups of houses were clustered together for protection. This is indicated by the names of places such as Wang Wu Chai □ and by the frequent references to fortified places in the legends. To-day there [Page 23] are none to be found. One explanation given by Ch'uan Miao friends is that the danger of fire was too great so that people no longer built their houses so close together. There are two other possible reasons. One is that the Chinese destroyed the strongholds in war and to prevent future rebellions, and the other is that there is no longer danger of raids and attacks from the Lolos. Chinese histories actually mention the destruction of the strongholds' [121] We are unsure as to how destructive those raids and feuds were or which tactics were commonly used. We have provisionally assumed sack rather than looting alone, but this is open to review. Nevertheless, during the rebellions, raids were accompanied by sack, massacres, and destruction rather than looting alone: 'Among the leaders, Shi Liudeng alone set forth a policy on Han recruitment, ordering that “Those who killed any Han people who had seized crop land in Miao territory, and burned their houses, were to have the land distributed to them at once, and only those Han who were willing to join the band would escape death.”89 Two Han men who joined his force left confessions. One was a tobacco-leaf trader acquaintance of Shi Liudeng who “joined up”at his request and who burned and robbed some thirty zhai, and the other a tile roofer who had been approached by two men, one a relative of his Miao wife: “Shi Liudeng invited [me] to burn and rob some cunzhai, and would I like to join the gang?”90 There is no hint of a wider purpose here. A certain Long Duma ᚊᗑᏖ added that there were “quite a few” Hanjian in Liudeng’s force, and nineteen Han appear in a list of sixty-nine captives.91 These Han, none of them serving as troop leaders, constituted a small fraction of the thousands of rebels he recruited. Even for Liudeng’s force, the assertion that “a sizable number of Chinese settlers had taken up with the rebels” seems overdrawn.' [122] Sutton mentions pillaging: 'The crisis of early 1795 upended the social system created by this differentiation. The soldiers were too few and scattered to withstand the Miao, who took control of the roads, and in some places (particularly in Qianzhou) the “guests” fled their homes. Thus turen, as people in the middle, played a crucial role in the revolt. Left to fend for themselves, the temptation might have been to ally with the Miao rebels and pillage the roadside valley lands, but - whether out of caution (they were more familiar than the Miao were with the nature of imperial power) or on account of hostile feelings against their Miao neighbors - they organized defensive forces of varying size and waited uneasily to see what would happen. Governor-general Bi Yuan ฅީ (1739-1797) and governor Jiang Sheng deliberately courted the turen. Their winning over of Zhang Tingzhong of Yongshun, which the Hunan literatus Yan Ruyi ᣤڕᅄ (1759-1826) said saved Chenzhou and Yongshun from the Miao,113 was their greatest success. In general, the diverse peoples called the turen effectively exploited their position as people in the middle, siding with Qing in 1795, though not without dithering and mistrust. Qing reliance on the relatively more acculturated groups in 1795 presaged the P.R.C. policy in the autonomous region. Eventually the turen would grow by external augmentation and natural increase and see themselves as a single group. The (Mandarin-speaking) Tujia of the P. R. C. now predominate in population and political power in the ten-county West Hunan Tujia and Miao Autonomous Region.' [123]

♠ Rape ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Deportation ♣ present ♥ During the war, armed groups of Hmong pushed Chinese settlers out when possible: 'The great revolt of the Miao of western Hunan -the easternmost branch of the Miao peoples dispersed over southern China- began in the last year of the Qianlong emperor's reign. It was a complete surprise to Han Chinese in this ethnic frontier region, and to Qing officialdom. Miao bands raided Han settlements in a region extending across the three subprefectures of Yongsui, Fenghuang, and Qianzhou into parts of Guizhou and Sichuan provinces. [...] Larger attacks followed into the Qianzhou capital, which was several times overrun and burned, and into Pushi, the unwalled commercial center on the Yuan River. Two isolated walled official encampments, Zhengda and Chounao, were besieged, and so for a full two months was the remote capital of Yongsui. Qing reinforcements were ambushed, with the total loss of 700 or 800 in one case and an entire baggage train with thousands of guards in another; and rebel bands ranging from 500 to 5,000 in strength roamed over the region, killing or putting to flight Han Chinese and burning their settlements.' [124] After the rebellions, Chinese troops dispersed, removed and resettled parts of the Miao population: 'During the Qing, uprisings and military encounters escalated. There were major disturbances in western Hunan (1795-1806) and a continuous series of rebellions in Guizhou (1854-1872). Chinese policies toward the Miao shifted among assimilation, containment in "stockaded villages," dispersal, removal, and extermination. The frequent threat of " Miao rebellion" caused considerable anxiety to the state; in actuality, many of these uprisings included Bouyei, Dong, Hui, and other ethnic groups, including Han settlers and demobilized soldiers. At issue were heavy taxation, rising landlordism, rivalries over local resources, and official corruption.' [125] We have assumed that dispersal and removal may include both expulsion and deportation. Many Miao were forced to leave their home areas permanently: 'The greatest of the three wars occurred from 1854 to 1873. Zhang Xiu-mei led this revolt in Guizhou until his capture and death in Changsha, Hunan. This revolt affected over one million people and all the neighbouring provinces. By the time the war ended Professor Wu said only 30 percent of the Miao were left in their home regions. This defeat led to the Hmong people migrating out of China.'[126]

♠ Expulsion ♣ present ♥ During the war, armed groups of Hmong pushed Chinese settlers out when possible: 'The great revolt of the Miao of western Hunan -the easternmost branch of the Miao peoples dispersed over southern China- began in the last year of the Qianlong emperor's reign. It was a complete surprise to Han Chinese in this ethnic frontier region, and to Qing officialdom. Miao bands raided Han settlements in a region extending across the three subprefectures of Yongsui, Fenghuang, and Qianzhou into parts of Guizhou and Sichuan provinces. [...] Larger attacks followed into the Qianzhou capital, which was several times overrun and burned, and into Pushi, the unwalled commercial center on the Yuan River. Two isolated walled official encampments, Zhengda and Chounao, were besieged, and so for a full two months was the remote capital of Yongsui. Qing reinforcements were ambushed, with the total loss of 700 or 800 in one case and an entire baggage train with thousands of guards in another; and rebel bands ranging from 500 to 5,000 in strength roamed over the region, killing or putting to flight Han Chinese and burning their settlements.' [127] After the rebellions, Chinese troops dispersed, removed and resettled parts of the Hmong population: 'During the Qing, uprisings and military encounters escalated. There were major disturbances in western Hunan (1795-1806) and a continuous series of rebellions in Guizhou (1854-1872). Chinese policies toward the Miao shifted among assimilation, containment in "stockaded villages," dispersal, removal, and extermination. The frequent threat of " Miao rebellion" caused considerable anxiety to the state; in actuality, many of these uprisings included Bouyei, Dong, Hui, and other ethnic groups, including Han settlers and demobilized soldiers. At issue were heavy taxation, rising landlordism, rivalries over local resources, and official corruption.' [128] We have assumed that dispersal and removal may include both expulsion and deportation. Many Miao were forced to leave their home areas permanently: 'The greatest of the three wars occurred from 1854 to 1873. Zhang Xiu-mei led this revolt in Guizhou until his capture and death in Changsha, Hunan. This revolt affected over one million people and all the neighbouring provinces. By the time the war ended Professor Wu said only 30 percent of the Miao were left in their home regions. This defeat led to the Hmong people migrating out of China.'[129]

♠ Enslavement ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Imprisonment ♣ present ♥ Chinese troops captured, tried and executed rebel leaders: 'Defeated on every front, the Miao forces turned to defensive tactics - cutting paths and building fortifications, which succeeded in slowing the Qing advance, and making hamlet-burning raids on Miao who had surrendered to the official side. One by one the chief leaders were captured or killed, partly through a strategy of betrayal. Qing forces gradually moved through the mountains, destroying whole hamlets along the way and methodically securing supply lines and establishing encampments on the slopes and heights. Finally they pushed through to Pinglong ؓᣃ, the rebel headquarters, in January, 1796. Some rebels fought on for a full year. Local troops would continue wiping out rebel remnants and burning hamlets of dubious loyalty for another ten years.' [130] 'The official purpose and rationale need to be spelled out further if we are to understand the form of the suppression. Punishments meted out to captives had their positive side, playing an essential part in the restoration of Qing authority. Here we are obliged, like Michel Foucault, to adopt the perspective of those who ordered or were expected to witness the punishment.132 Death penalties according to Qing (and Ming) law were in principle to be approved at the capital. The trial and execution of the top leaders took place at Rehe, by the Grand Council itself, in a visible reassertion of the central authority challenged by the revolt. Miao leaders who survived the fighting and were captured (for example, Wu Tianban, Shi Sanbao, Wu Tingyi, and two of Liudeng’s adoptive sons, Shi Laoqiao and Shi Laoer) were sent there to be tried and sentenced to a slow lingering death. Sanbao’s elder son, Shi Laoguan, who was not on good terms with his father, was judged as meriting only immediate decapitation.133 For those considered to be ringleaders, public exposure followed execution. Shi Liudeng was fortunate to die on the battlefield. His head, defaced by bullet wounds, was picked out from a pile of Miao heads and dispatched to Peking along with his live adoptive sons.134 The Qing commander Fukang’an assembled a Miao crowd to watch Wu Bayue executed by castration and beheading along with the shaker Shi Laoyan (the Lofty General) and the supposed Hanjian Yang Laolong, and kept their heads for public exhibition once Pinglong had been captured.135 Wu Bayue’s sons, Tingyu and Tingying, did survive to be taken home for their lingering execution.136 Their brother, Tingli, who had died of sickness, “already punished by hell,” was dug up so that his head could be set up alongside those of his brothers.137 At Cucumber Hamlet Fukang’an gleefully dug up seven grave mounds and scattered into the wind the dust of what he presumed tobe the bones of Shi Sanbao’s ancestors.' [131] Earlier arrests of Hmong by Chinese authorities had played a role in catalyzing anti-Chinese resentment: 'How do we explain their hostility to Qing officialdom? It was not, as several admitted freely in interrogation, because of heavy taxation. The Miao were exempt from the land tax and the runners’ and subofficials’ surcharges that in practice would go along with its collection.22 But anger at official treatment may have played a role. Experiences in the subprefectural courts provoked Miao irritation; it was perfectly natural for subprefects, isolated in a peripheral region, to take the side of settlers against the barely civilized Miao. But one incident seems to have been especially resented. It had occurred at Goubu ֍ᇖʳin the mountainous fringe of Fenghuang eight years earlier.23 Hundreds of Miao from its three hamlets had been arrested and executed after several residents had forcibly resisted arrest when accused of waylaying a passing Han merchant. Wu Longdeng had helped officials to settle the case. Men surnamed Shi had been particularly affected, and the Shi clan was said to have been particularly angry at the outcome.' [132]

♠ Destruction ♣ present ♥ Hmong and Qing alike systematically burned and destroyed hamlets: 'The great revolt of the Miao of western Hunan -the easternmost branch of the Miao peoples dispersed over southern China- began in the last year of the Qianlong emperor's reign. It was a complete surprise to Han Chinese in this ethnic frontier region, and to Qing officialdom. Miao bands raided Han settlements in a region extending across the three subprefectures of Yongsui, Fenghuang, and Qianzhou into parts of Guizhou and Sichuan provinces. [...] Larger attacks followed into the Qianzhou capital, which was several times overrun and burned, and into Pushi, the unwalled commercial center on the Yuan River. Two isolated walled official encampments, Zhengda and Chounao, were besieged, and so for a full two months was the remote capital of Yongsui. Qing reinforcements were ambushed, with the total loss of 700 or 800 in one case and an entire baggage train with thousands of guards in another; and rebel bands ranging from 500 to 5,000 in strength roamed over the region, killing or putting to flight Han Chinese and burning their settlements.' [133] 'There were formerly many fortified places called in Chinese chai tzŭ □ where groups of houses were clustered together for protection. This is indicated by the names of places such as Wang Wu Chai □ and by the frequent references to fortified places in the legends. To-day there [Page 23] are none to be found. One explanation given by Ch'uan Miao friends is that the danger of fire was too great so that people no longer built their houses so close together. There are two other possible reasons. One is that the Chinese destroyed the strongholds in war and to prevent future rebellions, and the other is that there is no longer danger of raids and attacks from the Lolos. Chinese histories actually mention the destruction of the strongholds' [134] 'Defeated on every front, the Miao forces turned to defensive tactics - cutting paths and building fortifications, which succeeded in slowing the Qing advance, and making hamlet-burning raids on Miao who had surrendered to the official side. One by one the chief leaders were captured or killed, partly through a strategy of betrayal. Qing forces gradually moved through the mountains, destroying whole hamlets along the way and methodically securing supply lines and establishing encampments on the slopes and heights. Finally they pushed through to Pinglong ؓᣃ, the rebel headquarters, in January, 1796. Some rebels fought on for a full year. Local troops would continue wiping out rebel remnants and burning hamlets of dubious loyalty for another ten years.' [135] Hmong rebels had also systematically destroyed Chinese military installations in earlier confrontations: 'During the Ts'ung Cheng reign period /1628/ /the end of the Ming dynasty/, the Miao rebelled, demolishing the guard stations and leveling the border wall. The “Great Wall” to blockade Miao country disappeared. The 7,800 guard troops /shou ping/ in the Miao area of the Ming dynasty were reduced to 1,600 men at the beginning of the Ch'ing dynasty. When the rebellion of Wu San-kwei was pacified and all was peaceful again, there was another reduction of 500 men, leaving 1,100 men. Military strengh was slight and the defense system was relaxed. Further, following the change from native headmen to Chinese officials, and the use of Chinese as the head of every hundred families, intercourse between the Chinese and the Miao was no longer prohibited. In the twenty-ninth year of Ch'ien Lung /i.e. 1764/, in view of the Miao having undergone acculturation for a long time, they were allowed to intermarry with the Chinese. The original idea was to change the Miao by teaching, but with the passing of time evils developed, when rapacious Chinese under the pretext of trade entered the Miao area and seduced crafty Miao to enter into thievery. Unlike soldiers they entered Miao country for personal reasons and mistreated the Miao. The Miao made a pretext of these guest men's exploitations and encroachments on their land and banded together to make trouble, and brought about the great rebellion during the Ch'ien Lung /1736-95/ and Chia Ch'ing /1796-1820/ reign periods. After the rebellion was put down, the Manchu court realized that the time was yet inopportune to change the Miao by teaching, and the blockade policy was once more used. The various hsiens along the Miao border were heavily garrisoned for protection.' [136]

♠ Torture ♣ present ♥ Confessions by Hmong rebels were collected by the Qing authorities through torture and recorded in gonci or gondan. [137] 'Over eighty confessions gongci ࠎဲ, gongdan ࠎ໢) were recorded and preserved, in the customary first-person style, some perfunctory, some in detailed question and answer form. Confessions extracted under torture, as these often were, in the certain imminence of death, may be less or more reliable than sworn testimony, but since most of the leaders were captured for trial, it is possible to crosscheck their testimony, and this testimony will be a principal source of this essay.' [138] According to Sutton, some rebel leaders (including Han 'traitors') faced public mutilaton and torture prior to execution: 'The wartime situation allowed flexibility, even a degree of imagination, in the forms of punishment and execution. The Han traitors (Hanjian), who we have seen were mostly low-level spies or artisans, were sliced alive in public, usually where they had lived or in front of the troops, for example, Tian Yingqiao.139 Still more gruesome deaths were reserved for the most charismatic middle-level Miao leaders who had quickly risen to leadership in organization and battle. Shi Daike, the bold nephew of Shi Liudeng, was castrated and borne from zhai to zhai in a wooden cage like an animal, his wounds slowly festering. His head would be removed and exposed in the place where he died.140 Similarly treated was Long Laoer, a man of self-confessed wild character and enormous strength who was known as Wild Bull Long among the Miao, received the title of general from Shi Sanbao, and probably led the rebel’s most notorious success, the rout and extermination of commander Ming’antu’s ڜࣔቹ force at Yayou.141 On the battlefield he was glimpsed on horseback, his head tied in a red kerchief, and at the height of the revolt, according to his unrepentant testimony, controlled (the fighters of) as many as thirty-six zhai. After his capture, he too was carried round from zhai to zhai, in each subjected to unnamed forms of exemplary torture, and finally put to death.' [139]

♠ Mutilation ♣ present ♥ There is evidence of mutilation on a large scale during the Ming Dynasty (large-scale young male castration), but not the Qing Dynasty. But the bodies of Hmong rebel leaders and their few Han allies were mutilated during public executions (by castration, slicing, decapitation etc) and their heads were exhibited to the public: 'The official purpose and rationale need to be spelled out further ifwe are to understand the form of the suppression. Punishments meted out to captives had their positive side, playing an essential part in the restoration of Qing authority. Here we are obliged, like Michel Foucault, to adopt the perspective of those who ordered or were expected to witness the punishment.132 Death penalties according to Qing (and Ming) law were in principle to be approved at the capital. The trial and execution of the top leaders took place at Rehe, by the Grand Council itself, in a visible reassertion of the central authority challenged by the revolt. Miao leaders who survived the fighting and were captured (for example, Wu Tianban, Shi Sanbao, Wu Tingyi, and two of Liudeng’s adoptive sons, Shi Laoqiao and Shi Laoer) were sent there to be tried and sentenced to a slow lingering death. Sanbao’s elder son, Shi Laoguan, who was not on good terms with his father, was judged as meriting only immediate decapitation.133 For those considered to be ringleaders, public exposure followed execution. Shi Liudeng was fortunate to die on the battlefield. His head, defaced by bullet wounds, was picked out from a pile of Miao heads and dispatched to Peking along with his live adoptive sons.134 The Qing commander Fukang’an assembled a Miao crowd to watch Wu Bayue executed by castration and beheading along with the shaker Shi Laoyan (the Lofty General) and the supposed Hanjian Yang Laolong, and kept their heads for public exhibition once Pinglong had been captured.135 Wu Bayue’s sons, Tingyu and Tingying, did survive to be taken home for their lingering execution.136 Their brother, Tingli, who had died of sickness, “already punished by hell,” was dug up so that his head could be set up alongside those of his brothers.137 At Cucumber Hamlet Fukang’an gleefully dug up seven grave mounds and scattered into the wind the dust of what he presumed tobe the bones of Shi Sanbao’s ancestors.' [140] 'The wartime situation allowed flexibility, even a degree of imagination, in the forms of punishment and execution. The Han traitors (Hanjian), who we have seen were mostly low-level spies or artisans, were sliced alive in public, usually where they had lived or in front of the troops, for example, Tian Yingqiao.139 Still more gruesome deaths were reserved for the most charismatic middle-level Miao leaders who had quickly risen to leadership in organization and battle. Shi Daike, the bold nephew of Shi Liudeng, was castrated and borne from zhai to zhai in a wooden cage like an animal, his wounds slowly festering. His head would be removed and exposed in the place where he died.140 Similarly treated was Long Laoer, a man of self-confessed wild character and enormous strength who was known as Wild Bull Long among the Miao, received the title of general from Shi Sanbao, and probably led the rebel’s most notorious success, the rout and extermination of commander Ming’antu’s ڜࣔቹ force at Yayou.141 On the battlefield he was glimpsed on horseback, his head tied in a red kerchief, and at the height of the revolt, according to his unrepentant testimony, controlled (the fighters of) as many as thirty-six zhai. After his capture, he too was carried round from zhai to zhai, in each subjected to unnamed forms of exemplary torture, and finally put to death.' [141]

♠ Targeted massacre ♣ present ♥ Armed rebel groups raided hamlets that had been disloyal to the uprising. Chinese troops did the same to Hmong settlements whose loyalty to the Qing system was in question, even after the subjection of the uprising itself: 'Defeated on every front, the Miao forces turned to defensive tactics - cutting paths and building fortifications, which succeeded in slowing the Qing advance, and making hamlet-burning raids on Miao who had surrendered to the official side. One by one the chief leaders were captured or killed, partly through a strategy of betrayal. Qing forces gradually moved through the mountains, destroying whole hamlets along the way and methodically securing supply lines and establishing encampments on the slopes and heights. Finally they pushed through to Pinglong ؓᣃ, the rebel headquarters, in January, 1796. Some rebels fought on for a full year. Local troops would continue wiping out rebel remnants and burning hamlets of dubious loyalty for another ten years.' [142] Prior to the start of hostilities, Chinese authorities had executed en masse the inhabitants of some Hmong 

settlements after resisting arrest: 'How do we explain their hostility to Qing officialdom? It was not, as several admitted freely in interrogation, because of heavy taxation. The Miao were exempt from the land tax and the runners’ and subofficials’ surcharges that in practice would go along with its collection.22 But anger at official treatment may have played a role. Experiences in the subprefectural courts provoked Miao irritation; it was perfectly natural for subprefects, isolated in a peripheral region, to take the side of settlers against the barely civilized Miao. But one incident seems to have been especially resented. It had occurred at Goubu ֍ᇖʳin the mountainous fringe of Fenghuang eight years earlier.23 Hundreds of Miao from its three hamlets had been arrested and executed after several residents had forcibly resisted arrest when accused of waylaying a passing Han merchant. Wu Longdeng had helped officials to settle the case. Men surnamed Shi had been particularly affected, and the Shi clan was said to have been particularly angry at the outcome.' [143] 'Inter-tribal' raids may also have involved targeted massacres, but the sources are unclear on the matter: 'There were formerly many fortified places called in Chinese chai tzŭ □ where groups of houses were clustered together for protection. This is indicated by the names of places such as Wang Wu Chai □ and by the frequent references to fortified places in the legends. To-day there [Page 23] are none to be found. One explanation given by Ch'uan Miao friends is that the danger of fire was too great so that people no longer built their houses so close together. There are two other possible reasons. One is that the Chinese destroyed the strongholds in war and to prevent future rebellions, and the other is that there is no longer danger of raids and attacks from the Lolos. Chinese histories actually mention the destruction of the strongholds' [144] We have assumed that the destruction of individual hamlets and the targeting of specific categories of people (such as Hmong 'traitors' and 'suspect' clans and settlements) can be considered targeted massacres.

♠ General massacre ♣ present ♥ Qing forces destroyed whole hamlets when suppressing the 1795 insurrection. Supposedly disloyal hamlets were burned in their entirety through to 1806. [145] Hmong rebels burned Han settlements and killed or expelled their inhabitants: 'The great revolt of the Miao of western Hunan -the easternmost branch of the Miao peoples dispersed over southern China- began in the last year of the Qianlong emperor's reign. It was a complete surprise to Han Chinese in this ethnic frontier region, and to Qing officialdom. Miao bands raided Han settlements in a region extending across the three subprefectures of Yongsui, Fenghuang, and Qianzhou into parts of Guizhou and Sichuan provinces. [...] Larger attacks followed into the Qianzhou capital, which was several times overrun and burned, and into Pushi, the unwalled commercial center on the Yuan River. Two isolated walled official encampments, Zhengda and Chounao, were besieged, and so for a full two months was the remote capital of Yongsui. Qing reinforcements were ambushed, with the total loss of 700 or 800 in one case and an entire baggage train with thousands of guards in another; and rebel bands ranging from 500 to 5,000 in strength roamed over the region, killing or putting to flight Han Chinese and burning their settlements.' [146] We have assumed that these larger anti-Han campaigns can be classified as 'general massacres'. Expert feedback is needed on the matter, as we have found no precise figures on the (absolute or relative) number of Han Chinese killed during those raids. 'General massacre' may accordingly apply to some areas more than others.

♠ Extermination ♣ present ♥ Diamond claims 'extermination' as a tactic used by the Chinese against the Hmong: 'During the Qing Dynasty the Miao fought three wars against the empire.[11] In 1735 in the southeastern province of Guizhou, the Miao rose up against the government's forced assimilation. Eight counties involving 1,224 villages fought until 1738 when the revolt ended. According to Xiangtan University Professor Wu half the Miao population were affected by the war.'[147] 'During the Qing, uprisings and military encounters escalated. There were major disturbances in western Hunan (1795-1806) and a continuous series of rebellions in Guizhou (1854-1872). Chinese policies toward the Miao shifted among assimilation, containment in "stockaded villages," dispersal, removal, and extermination. The frequent threat of " Miao rebellion" caused considerable anxiety to the state; in actuality, many of these uprisings included Bouyei, Dong, Hui, and other ethnic groups, including Han settlers and demobilized soldiers. At issue were heavy taxation, rising landlordism, rivalries over local resources, and official corruption.' [148] Expert feedback is needed on the matter, as we have found no precise figures on the (absolute or relative) number of Han Chinese killed during those raids. 'Extermination' may accordingly apply to some regions more than others.

♠ Ethnocide ♣ present ♥ Some sources characterize the uprising as resistance against forced assimilation: 'During the Qing Dynasty the Miao fought three wars against the empire.[11] In 1735 in the southeastern province of Guizhou, the Miao rose up against the government's forced assimilation. Eight counties involving 1,224 villages fought until 1738 when the revolt ended. According to Xiangtan University Professor Wu half the Miao population were affected by the war.'[149] Diamond claims 'extermination' as a tactic used by the Chinese against the Hmong: 'During the Qing Dynasty the Miao fought three wars against the empire.[11] In 1735 in the southeastern province of Guizhou, the Miao rose up against the government's forced assimilation. Eight counties involving 1,224 villages fought until 1738 when the revolt ended. According to Xiangtan University Professor Wu half the Miao population were affected by the war.'[150] 'During the Qing, uprisings and military encounters escalated. There were major disturbances in western Hunan (1795-1806) and a continuous series of rebellions in Guizhou (1854-1872). Chinese policies toward the Hmong shifted among assimilation, containment in "stockaded villages," dispersal, removal, and extermination. The frequent threat of " Miao rebellion" caused considerable anxiety to the state; in actuality, many of these uprisings included Bouyei, Dong, Hui, and other ethnic groups, including Han settlers and demobilized soldiers. At issue were heavy taxation, rising landlordism, rivalries over local resources, and official corruption.' [151] Many Hmong were forced to leave their home areas permanently, even migrating out of China: 'The greatest of the three wars occurred from 1854 to 1873. Zhang Xiu-mei led this revolt in Guizhou until his capture and death in Changsha, Hunan. This revolt affected over one million people and all the neighbouring provinces. By the time the war ended Professor Wu said only 30 percent of the Miao were left in their home regions. This defeat led to the Hmong people migrating out of China.'[152] Chinese authorities sought to replace 'native' forms of social organization with a class system of their own making in order to further political integration with the empire. This attempt to displace non-Chinese ethnic affiliations and forms of organization was counterproductive and, according to Sutton, inadvertently contributed to ethnogenesis: 'The post-war policies had large effects on both Miao and turen. The continuing suppression, vigorously conducted from hamlet to hamlet by Fu Nai ແⷘʳof Fenghuang to accomplish the late Qianlong emperor’s draconian cleansing policy, permanently removed charismatic Miao leadership, wiped out many communities, and replaced the parallel (if unequal) Miao and Han Chinese social hierarchies with a class system where the great majority of Miao were poor peasants under the dominance of turen (from the mid-twentieth century, “Tujia”) and allied to external Han Chinese authority. On the other hand, closer political integration with the empire introduced an (albeit rickety) ladder of success as a new Miao militia force took over local constabulary duties, and assimilated Miao men were given new educational opportunities. Self-consciousness tends to increase in contact conditions whether in unequal competition between groups or in violent confrontation, and it is likely that neither the suppression nor the renewed trend toward acculturation altered the sense of Miao consciousness that had intensified in the decades since incorporation and the subsequent wave of Han in-migration, and had found expression in the revolt of 1795-1797. On present evidence, it seems reasonable to describe that revolt as a key phase in Miao ethnogenesis. The modern Miao nationality had emerged at least in part of the southwest, with the conversion of the Chinese term “Miao” into something felt and acted upon as well as recognized by others. But we should repeat that local Miao consciousness took only the Eastern Miao as its significant political community. This ethno-regionalism, recognizing no broad Miao /Hmong community, did not change until later, in the twentieth century. Thus the local clans in western Hunan would not make common cause with the “Miao” risings, correctly labeled multi-ethnic, which spread over much of the neighboring province of Guizhou in the decade beginning in 1864.' [153] We are unsure whether this meets our own criteria for 'ethnocide' in the sense of a systematic attempt to displace a subjected culture with that of the victor. We have coded 'present' for the time being, but this is open to review and in need of further confirmation.

Archaeological proxies:

♠ Skeletal evidence of violence ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Mass burials ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Settlement destruction ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Pictorial evidence of warfare ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

List of Wars[edit]

1735-1738 Miaoist Rebellion 1795-1806 Miaoist Rebellion 1854-1873 Miaoist Rebellion

Ritual variables[edit]

A collective ritual is a ritual in which two or more people participate. With the official cult we refer to the set of collective ritual practices that are most closely associated with legitimation of the power structure (including elites, if any).

♠ RA ♣ Eva Brandl ♥

♠ Editor ♣ Daniel Mullins ♥

♠ Expert ♣ ♥

NB: The Hmong are not coded for in the Ritual Database [154]. The below rituals were derived from Chinese-period ethnography and are thus largely based on inference. Furthermore, there was considerable variability among the different Hmong groups when it comes to ritual practice. The codes are accordingly open to review; consistency in particular is a concern on this data sheet as rituals practiced by one Hmong group may be celebrated differently among others. Expert feedback is needed on the matter.

NBB: 'The Chinese called the Hmong the Miao or Meo, which means, depending on which linguistic historian you read, 'barbarians', 'bumpkins', 'people who sound like cats', or 'wild uncultivated grasses'. In any case, it was an insult. ('Hmong', the name they prefer themselves, is usually said to mean 'free men', but some scholars say that, like 'Inuit', 'Dine', and many other tribal names the world over, it simply means 'the people').' [155]

The following general description was extracted from eHRAF: 'Religious beliefs and activities vary by locale and subethnic identity. The situation is further complicated by partial adoption of elements of folk Daoism and Buddhism, or by conversion to Christianity (as among segments of the White and Flowery Miao). Traditional religious beliefs concern powerful suprahuman forces associated with sacred groves, stones, caves, and other natural phenomena, as well as with bridges and wells. Other protective spirits guard the household and hamlet. The latter are sometimes thought of as dragons. It is believed that at death, the soul divides into three parts, one of which returns to protect the household as an ancestral spirit. There is also concern with evil spirits and with ghosts of those who died bad deaths and who may cause illness and misfortune. Religious beliefs are supported by a complex series of sung or chanted poetic myths, which treat the creation of the universe, the doings of divine beings and culture heroes, and early Miao history.' [156] 'Most religious ritual is performed or guided by various part-time specialists who act as priests, diviners, or shamans for the local community or for kin groups. Most of them are males. They engage in ordinary work, and only the most important religious activities require them to don special items of dress and decoration to mark them from others. There are no written texts for learning the chants, songs, dances, and rituals: they are memorized. If called by a family, specialists receive a small payment (often in foodstuffs) for their assistance. Shamans play a key role at funerals and postburial rites. They are also involved in analysis and healing of illness: some are skilled in herbal medicine as well as ritual procedures. Shamans also provide explanations of the possible causes of misfortune and can provide protective amulets. Ceremonies on behalf of the village community or a gathering of kin from several villages are conducted by skilled male elders who function as priests, following ritual procedures, administering the necessary animal and food sacrifices, and chanting the songs and myths without going into trance or communicating directly with the supernaturals and spirits. Some ceremonies are led by the male head of household on behalf of his immediate family.' [157] 'The calendrical year holds a number of set ceremonies that vary from group to group in content, purpose, and timing. For example, as of the 1990s some groups celebrated the lunar New Year along with their Han neighbors, whereas others celebrated the year's start in the tenth lunar month, following the harvest, and marked it with bullfights and cattle sacrifices. Others marked the New Year with cockfights or sacrifice of pigs and chickens, or intervillage assemblages enlivened by antiphonal singing, dancing, and the playing of the lusheng . Among the important festivals found in many (not all) Miao communities are the Dragon Boat Festival, which is synchronic with the Han festivities to a large extent, and the Mountain Flower festivals, which were an important institution for bringing together marriageable young people from different hamlets. The Drum Society festivals are held by dispersed kin groups to honor their ancestors every seven, ten, or twelve years, and are not strictly tied to the calendar. Most festivals involve the lavish offering of animal sacrifices, and for this reason the state has discouraged them.' [158]

The Hmong were criticized by the Qing Emperor Jiaqing for their cattle sacrifices.[159] 'On the eighth day of their fourth lunar month (around mid-May), the Miao celebrate a festival during which they offer sacrifices to their ancestors and cultural heroes. This festival commemorates the day in which the heroes Ya Yi and Ya Nu died in battle while preventing a cruel ruler from his cruel custom of annually forcing the Miao to choose one of their beautiful young women to be his concubine. At the festival, they sing, play reed pipes (lusheng in Chinese) and bonze drums, and dance to honor their ancestors, ensure a good harvest and drive away evil spirits. On special occasions such as this, the Miao women wear large quantities of silver necklaces, bracelets and headdresses which jingle when they dance. This silver jewelry is handed down as a family heirloom.'[160]

Graham is the only source reviewed so far that describes initiation ceremonies [161]. We have therefore chosen to exclude initiation rituals.

The ethnography provides on overview of the festival cycle of some Hmong groups:

'Festivals were abundant and differed widely by region, although the New Year was commonly of central importance. Everywhere the Miao lusheng or bamboo reed pipe organ was a key musical instrument along with drums, different horns and flutes, a kind of jew's harp, and a long tubular instrument called the mantong. Blowing through leaves also was widespread. Multiple genres of song were accompanied by numerous conventions for their social usages. Other activities at festivals included processional dancing, bullfights, horse races, cock and other bird fights, mountain climbing, ball tossing, and dragon boat races.' [162] 'Although the calendar used by the Miao -I is identical to that of the Chinese and likewise the year is divided into twelve months, the festivals observed are somewhat different in importance. The Hua Miao, the Ch 'ing Miao and the Chung-chia, for instance, regard the sixth day of the sixth month as the greatest festival. The following is a month by month account of the festivals of the Miao -I at An-shun during the year.' [163] 'The First Month. The first day of the first month is the beginning of the year. The Miao -I in this district would stick up paper money on the door of the house, which is also decorated with red peppers strung together with scented rice straw. Some of the Chung-chia people imitate the Chinese by asking calligraphers to pen symmetrical New Year verses for the door, [Page 99] 180 cont. and then hang out knots of scented rice straw, but no red peppers. These decorations are in expectation of a prosperous year.' [164] 'After having celebrated “The Big Year” on the thirtieth day of the twelfth month and having decorated the door on the New Year's day, the Hua Miao and the Ch'ing Miao would remain at home to rest without doing any work. The food for the New Year was prepared in advance on a lucky day (dragon and dog days are lucky), and it is not cooked again until another lucky day comes around.181 So on New Year's day there is no kitchen drudgery as only pre-cooked meals are eaten. The New Year's day being the first of the year, everything has to be auspicious and inhibitions are many. For instance, 1) no sewing is done by women at home; 2) nothing is taken into the house from outside; 3) no water is carried; 4) no knife is used; 5) no one is allowed to go barefooted and shoes must be worn; 6) no cursing is allowed; 7) no rapping on the wall is allowed; 8) the floor must not be swept; 9) no collection of debt is permitted. Besides, there are the proverbial “three days of liberty” when parents would allow their sons and daughters unrestrained freedom in the pursuit of recreation and happiness on the first, second and third days of the year. After this period the children once more submit themselves to parental restraint. On the first day of the year the old and young are clothed in new garments and have fun all day long. Only the Hsiung and Yang families among the Ch'ing Miao have the custom of worshipping ancestors in the evening. At the time of the sacrifice, the head of the family would spread a straw mat on the floor of the middle room or the side room and place on it incense and candles as well as three bowls of rice. In each bowl is pitched a piece of pork on a bamboo stick with three straw knots to represent the ancestors. In addition there are three bowls of beancurd and three pieces of tz'u-pa /glutinous rice balls/. They call out aloud to ask their ancestors to pass the New Year with them. Then the male members of the family begin to kowtow in the order of their age. After the paper money is completely burned, they gather up the things on the straw mat. The rice straw and the bamboo [Page 100] 181 cont. sticks are thrown into the temple of the Earth God outside the village.' [165] 'The New Year activities of the Chung-chia are slightly different from those of the Hua Miao and Ch'ing- Miao. On the first day of the year they also wear new clothes and decorate their doorway. At about seven o'clock in the morning they make sacrifices to their ancestors in the hall with several bowls of rice and meat while incense and candles are burned and fire-crackers are set off. The whole family, old and young, male and female, all participate in the ceremony as they perform the ritual of “three kneelings and nine kowtows.” After the sacrifice, the family settles down to a New Year feast in the hall, after which they stop working and laugh and joke all day. Their restrictions are similar to those of the Hua Miao and Ch'ing Miao. But the Chung-chia have a peculiar superstition that if on the first day of the year a dog should bark after cockcrow, there would surely be a robbery in the village; and if the crow caws first, there would surely be many sicknesses among them during the year; on the other hand, if another animal should make a noise before the dog and the crow, then there would be a very lucky year ahead. All these superstitious notions are firmly believed in by the Chung-Chia, and for this reason early in the morning of the New Year's day all the families would cock their ears to listen to the bird or animal that first makes noise. On the second day of the New Year, the Hua Miao and the Ch'ing Miao would gather their family members after breakfast and with spades on their shoulders and wearing straw hats they would march off to their farms to do a little ploughing and digging, the idea being that this first “earth-removing” inaugurates a year's agricultural activities. With the Chung-chia, there is no definite day for the beginning of farm work, but it is generally around the tenth day of the first month. During the first three days of the year the Hua Miao, the Ch'ing Miao and the chung-chia would all stay home without going out for fear of meeting with unlucky events. On the fourth day the villages become astir with New Year visits between [Page 101] 182 cont. friends and relatives, and the younger generations pay respects to their elders (The New Year gifts for the children vary from ten to twenty cents.) When they exchange visits and greetings they bring with them a couple of home-made tz'u pa (each about 1 sheng of rice), candies and refreshments as gifts. The host and hostesses must entertain the visitors with tea and wine. The tenant farmers also present similar New Year gifts to their landlords, who in return would give them pieces of cloth or other household articles. As a rule such New Year greetings do not extend beyond the twelfth day though intimate relatives may offer theirs until the fifteenth. If a relative who has kept up these New Year visits throughout the past years fails to turn up, the family will be greatly offended. The Miao -I take the New Year greetings very seriously, and hence they should not be neglected.' [166] 'The Hua Miao and the Ch'ing Miao in the hsien district have a custom of flower dance. There is a fixed location for the dancing ground, called the “flower bed.” The dates for flower dances are set according to schedules in various places, and are generally between the fourth and the fifteenth day of the first month. On this occasion visitors gather like clouds in great jubilation, and it is indeed the most important festival of the Hua Miao and the Ch'ing Miao throughout the year. The fifteenth day of the first month is the “Small New Year” with the Hua Miao and the Ch'ing Miao. That evening they put in front of the doorway a small table, on which are placed as sacrificial offerings a bowl of rice, a piece of meat and a cup of rice wine. Burning incense and lighting candles, they would kneel down and pray: “We pray to the Buddha tonight to guide us this year smoothly to wealth and prosperity.” After the prayer, the old and young, except the womenfolk, worship in turn. Then they sit down together for a feast in the hall. After dinner they have fun for the rest of the evening. The Chung-chia celebrate the “Small New Year” on the thirtieth day of the first month. Besides other delicacies at the table, every family makes tz'u-pa balls fried in oil, known as “eating oil balls.” They make sacrifices to their ancestors in great piety.' [167] 'The Second Month. In the second month all New Year festivities are over, and every one among the Miao -I must attend to his duties. If one does not work during the second month, he is adjudged an idler and is ridiculed. In the middle of the second month, four or five days after the beginning of spring /Feb. 5-18/ according to the lunar calendar, the Miao -I in the district have a custom similar to the Chinese there. Any tomb that is not yet three years old is visited by one or two male members of the family with a basket which contains a tray of beancurd, a piece of fried tz'u-pa, a tray of pork, a cup of wine, a bowl of rice, a pair of candles, nine sticks of incense and some paper money. These are offered in sacrifice. A small number of rich families would lay out a feast at the graveyard, and this is called “lan-shê.” The Third Month. On the third day of this month the Miao -I eat tz'u-pa made of buckwheat flour called “ch'iao-erh-pa.” In the Ching-ming season /April 5-19/ they sweep the grave, a custom known as “hanging the paper.” They stick new willow twigs on their door. On the Ch'ing-ming day they first visit the public grave (the oldest grave of the original ancestor), and then their private graves. In preparation for the visit to the public grave they buy collectively a huge pig as well as candles and incense, firecrackers, wine and delicacies. Members of the entire clan in the village go there to make sacrifices, after which they feast themselves at the grave. After the visit to the public grave they separately prepare items of sacrifice to be offered at their private graves. There are also a small number of rich families who would set up several dozen tables of feasts at the family graveyard to entertain the guests. A few days later, if the wind is mild and the weather fine, the mountain side would be dotted with men and women promenading and enjoying nature. The Fourth Month. The eighth day of this month is observed as a “Buddha-bathing festival” by the local Chinese. The Chung-chia in the hsien district would set up their ancestral tablets, make tz'u-pa, prepare wine and meat, and burn incense for sacrifice. The Chung-chia in this district as well as the Kuhuang Miao (one branch of the Hua Miao) in four or five areas [Page 103] 183 cont. consider this day as the birthday of the cow-king, and so all the cows in the field have a day of rest.' [168] 'The Fifth Month. The fifth day of this month is the Tuanyang festival, also known locally as “Tuan-wu.” The Miao -I families in the hsien district would steam glutinous rice on the fourth day and mash it into tz'u-pa the next morning. Every member of the family would receive a few pieces and these are eaten with maple sugar and crushed bean paste in the place of meals for that day. But it is 184 not a holiday and they still work as usual in the fields. Recently many Miao -I imitate the Chinese by hanging rush and artemisia leaves at the door, and at noon time they drink realgar wine and eat glutinous rice dumplings /wrapped in bamboo leaves/ and noodles instead of rice. After the transplantation of rice-plants in the fourth and fifth months and at the time of their flowering (called locally “yang flowers”) in the seventh and eighth months, the Hua Miao and the Ch'ing Miao both have a dancing festival as festive as the New Year flower dance. The Sixth Month. The temples of the local gods in all the Chinese and Miao -I villages in the district are scenes of great celebration on the sixth day of this month. The Miao -I build their local temples outside the village gate, and on this day they would hold processions in honor of the Earth God. The day before, the village head prepared in advance a big pig and many varieties of meats and vegetables. On the sixth day all the items of sacrifice are carried to the village gate and deposited there in front of the Earth God temple. After setting off the firecrackers, every family takes turns to perform a ritual before the temple. After the sacrifice the pork is divided up among the families, the quantity being designated by each family to be paid for in grain after the autumn harvest. The remainder of the pork together with the other meats and vegetables are cooked together on the spot in a huge cauldron and eaten by all the people present. After feasting each family brings home a small quantity of pork, from which a piece is cut off for sacrifice on the border of one's field. A string of paper money is also stuck there as a token to [Page 104] 184 cont. invoke a prosperous harvest. In the afternoon every family contributes a few dimes for the purchase of vegetables and sends a representative to the party, at which rules and regulations are discussed regarding indemnities for damages to crops. He who can write is asked to list the rules on a piece of white paper to be affixed at the village gate. Then on the top of a high mound near the village they set up a straw mark and let loose a din of firecrackers to announce to villages far and near that this village has already passed its laws so that none may go there to violate them.' [169] 'On this day the number of people making sacrifices before the Earth God temple among the Chung-chia is also large, but in addition each family has to prepare separate glutinous rice dumplings and a chicken for sacrifice to the ancestors. In the afternoon the children would bring dumplings and chicken legs to some nearby river banks to enjoy themselves. Toward evening they would wash their hands and feet in the river before coming home, and this is called “the first wash.” The Seventh Month. The first dragon day of this month is the “new crop festival.” On this day all the children of the Hua Miao and Ch'ing Miao 185 wear new clothes. In the morning they would go to the field, each plucking three bunches of grain stalks, which they cook in rice. They also cook a few ears of corn with some blue fish for sacrifice to the ancestors. After the ritual the whole family would sit down to a meal of new rice and corn. The custom of the Chung-chia is similar, except that after the sacrifice the new rice and corn are first fed to the dog of the house before they are eaten by men. According to their tradition, it is said that at the time of creation there was no rice in the world, and that a dog brought the seed from heaven for men to plant. It was only then that people had rice for food. So on the “new corp day ” each year rice is first fed to the dog to show that his benefaction has not been forgotten. Among the Chung-chia there is another superstition: from the “new crop day” to the time of the autumn harvest no one in the house, old or young, may sit on the doorsill so as to avoid misfortune.' [170] 'The Eighth Month. The fifteenth day of this month is the mid-autumn festival. The local Chinese have the custom of making offerings to the moon, which the Miao -I do not have. Before this date, however, some frolicsome fellows among them might steal a pumpkin from somebody's yard and on the eve of the fifteenth day would dress it up into the likeness of an infant, complete with garment and shoes, and wrap it inside a dress. While one man carries the pumpkin, another would walk behind, simulating baby talk or baby cry. They also carry with them different eatables and visit neighbors and relatives who do not have children. On arriving, they would set off firecrackers and then knock at the door to ask for entrance. The childless family, knowing the visit in advance, would prepare a feast to entertain the visitors in the hall. After entering the house, the visitors would take the pumpkin to an inner chamber and place it on a bed, imitating at the same time a child's crying. One visitor would then spit into the bed and exclaim: “The baby is wet!” On hearing this noise the owner of the house dashes into the room and invites the visitors to the feast. This performance is commonly known as “presenting the old pumpkin,” and is regarded by childless couples as a good omen for childbearing. If in the future the recipient should actually give birth to a son, the pumpkin bearers would be treated to another feast. The Ninth Month. The ninth day of the ninth month is the Ch'ung-yang festival. On this day the Miao -I families within the district all eat tz'u-pa and make wine, known as Ch'ung-yang wine. It is said that the wine made on this day is especially delicious in taste and can last for a whole year without becoming weak. The Tenth Month. No festivals. The Eleventh Month. No festivals. The Twelfth Month. The eighth day of this month is known as “La-pa,” on which the Miao -I have the custom of competing for the first bucket of water. The bearers are all women, who rise early in the morning to go to the nearest well to draw the first bucketful of water to carry home. It is used to cook rice for the animals, to wash the women's hair, and to brew [Page 106] 186 cont. tea. It is said that this tea, when drunk by old folks, can cure coughing. On this La-pa day the families cook the soft congee rice /chou/, known as “la-pa-chou,” instead of the hard, dry rice. This custom is the same as that of the local Chinese.' [171] 'The last day of the twelfth month is the day to banish all bad luck, and is known as the “Big New Year Eve.” On this day all the Miao -I families do a thorough house-cleaning. They go to the mountain to collect bamboo branches and tie them in a bundle to be used as a broom to brush away the dust accumulated during the year. They also wash their household implements and utensils, and thus tidy up the whole house to give it a completely new look both inside and outside. In the morning they make tz'u-pa to feed the cow and buy from the village fair many varieties of New Year delicacies. In the evening they put wine and food outside the gate as offerings to heaven and earth and their ancestors. After the sacrifice they gather together for dinner in the house. They pick out some rice and meat from the table to feed the dog. After dinner the elder of the house distributes cash presents to the children. No one goes to bed on the New Year Eve as candles burn, firecrackers resound, and singing and music from the reed-organ rend the air the whole night until dawn. This is known as keeping the vigil of the year.' [172]

Some sources report sexual licence among young people as part of Hmong festivals, but this is contested:

'Marriages generally require parental consent but are based on mutual attraction and choice. In the past, many communities had "youth houses" where unmarried young people could gather. Groups of young men traveled around to court girls in other villages. In the absence of parental consent, elopement was an alternative. Festivals and trips to periodic markets still provide an opportunity for young people to meet, engage in antiphonal singing and dancing, and establish new friendships. Since the 1950s, travel restrictions and state disapproval of premarital sexual behavior has increased the parental role in marriage arrangement. Marriages are monogamous. Marriage outside the dialect or language group is rare. Divorce and remarriages are permitted. Postmarital residence is usually in the man's home village but only the youngest son lives with his parents after his marriage, and in instances where there are no sons a family may bring in a son-in-law or an aged widow or widower might join her married daughter's household. In some areas, there is delayed transfer of the bride until after the birth of her first child, or the practice of starting out with residence with the bride's family.' [173] 'On the second or third days of the second moon, at tuan yang □, and on the sixth day of the sixth moon, men and women and boys and girls go to market. There they make advances to each other and a boy or a man goes home with a girl or a woman. On the way or in her home they are likely to enjoy sexual intercourse. They may or may not be married people. If anybody in the home of the woman or girl objects, a quarrel ensues. Generally no trouble is made by the wife or husband of either of the actors. But sometimes a woman who has irregular sexual relations with men other than her husband objects to her husband's doing likewise and in rare cases she commits suicide. It is said that among the Ch'uan Miao there are no harlots, women who habitually sell themselves for money and depend on that for a living. Sexual relations are generally the result of love affairs.' [174] 'Among the Miao the premarital sex life of the young men and women is rather free. When a virgin has intercourse with a man, her parents know about it but do not forbid it. On the contrary, they consider this evidence that the man finds their daughter desirable. Sometimes, the girl brings home her lover, and her parents will kill a chicken to entertain him. There are even public houses set up specially for the use of young men and women to gather together. For instance, in Chapter II reference was made to the Pa Chai Miao, recorded in Yung-sui T'ing Chih, to the effect that an empty shed was built near the village, where unmarried men and women gathered together to sing. If a couple fell in love, a cow was sent as a betrothal gift. Again, the unmarried men among the Ch'ing Chiang He Miao were called “lohan”; in the spring they would [Page 130] 94 cont. carry wine and food up the mountain, singing and dancing reciprocally. Those who became fond of each other would drink from an ox horn. There is the custom among the Miao of dancing for the new year, dancing for the moon, and singing for autumn. On such occasions, young men and women form groups and sing in response to each other all night until daybreak. After singing they mix with each other, drinking and joking, even to the extent of having sexual relations. This is called fang yeh “going wild.”' [175] 'The former marriage customs of the Miao were slightly different from their present ways. Yung-sui T'ing Chih says: “Miao marriage is just like a purchase. They do not follow the /Chinese/ custom of asking names (as a preliminary to fixing a betrothal) and sending presents to the bride's home to fix the betrothal. They only negotiate about the number of horses and cattle through a broker. The broker is a Miao marriage go-between. It definitely requires five or six horses or heads of cattle to initiate a trade for one wife. When the agreement [Page 131] 94 cont. is reached an inauspicious /sic/ day is chosen to welcome the wife. The bride wears a moon-white gown and walks holding a parasol, half open, half shut, called the shame-hiding parasol. Her father and mother, brothers, and relatives escort her to the husband's house. The dowry consists of everything from cattle and sheep and goats to plows and harrows. They do not enter by the main door but through a hole bored through a wall. Men and women sit together. The bride is not allowed to look left or right, or else the husband would be displeased for fear that shermay be fond of some one else. The couple takes each a bowl of rice, a piece of fish, and a cup of wine dregs. Next they visit the paternal uncles' houses in the same village, at each eating and drinking the same items. On their return home they are husband and wife, but they do not spend the night together.” It also says: “The Miao do not object to marriage between people of the same surname, but relatives do not marry. On the wedding night the bride sleeps with her mother, who leaves only when the groom gives her some silver as a gift 95, called the “mother's money” or “milk money.” It is generally about two or three liang of silver. A wealthy family, seeing a pretty girl, might order their son to drag the girl from behind. This is called “carrying off a woman and marrying her by force.” The girl's family attracted by their wealth, do not engage the girl to anyone else, but get a go-between to discuss betrothal presents. When a virgin has an affair with a man, her parents know about it but do not forbid it. On the contrary, they consider this evidence that the man finds her desirable. But, if one's wife or concubine is seduced, then they raise knives, facing each other, and money is required as compensation. If a husband and wife do not get along, the husband may divorce her and marry again, and the wife may do the same. As to improper sexual conduct, instances were very rare even in former days, and today the Miao have become more aware of ethical and moral obligations.” (What is recorded in the Miao Fang Pei Lan is to the same effect.)' [176] 'Youth. Young people grew up much less hedged about with conventions than were the Chinese of the locality. They worked and played together, as in the cleaning of stables, fishing in the pond, harvesting, and the New Year holiday. At that time girls sat about two fires in the space bounded by the buffalo bullfighting meadow, a bamboo thicket, a cluster of grave mounds, and the highway along the southern edge of the wood. There they embroidered, played the flute, and sang, as they entertained young men from other Cowrie Shell Miao villages. A group of women with their children sat about the third fire, but did not interfere with the teasing, snatching of turbans and ornaments, and chasing which went on. During this period boys from other villages stayed all night in the homes of this village, and a group went to market together. If there was sexual promiscuity at this time, it was not practised openly.' [177] 'Marriage among the Miao is mostly the result of love, but the mediation of the match-maker and the engagement ceremony are necessary before fixing the date of marriage. Young men and women 19 at the “liu sheng /reed-wind instrument/ dance” in the first lunar month may openly fall in love with each other without the intervention of parents or brothers of the family. In ordinary times, especially during the holidays, they may also court each other at will. So on the mountain slope or in the field we often observe scenes of “yao-ma-lang” (i.e., love-making), when they sing songs to each other in questions and answers. One party would ask a question in a song, and if the other party is willing she sings back the answer. These songs are extemporized, full of freedom and naturalness. Such serenades last till sunset when they begin to return home. After a suitable period of time, if their feelings persist then the parents would find a go-between to arrange the engagement. This system of love and marriage seem very free, yet there is no promiscuity. Their conduct is regulated by unwritten laws and they all have a high sense of decency. For instance, yao-ma-lang is carried on out of sight of old people, and yet it has to be within sight of passers-by. Furthermore, men and women must remain at least five feet apart, and necking and embracing are taboo. (The Long-skirt Miao not far away from them permit [Page 23] 19 cont. embracing.) So, pre-marital relations between men and women are rare if not altogether absent.' [178]

Given the contentious character of sexual licence in the ethnography, we have decided to provisionally code the respective variables as 'absent'.


Largest scale collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ New Year's Festival ♥ The New Year's Festival features prominently in the ethnography, although there is some variation in the importance of individual festivals among different Hmong groups. 'Festivals were abundant and differed widely by region, although the New Year was commonly of central importance. Everywhere the Miao lusheng or bamboo reed pipe organ was a key musical instrument along with drums, different horns and flutes, a kind of jew's harp, and a long tubular instrument called the mantong. Blowing through leaves also was widespread. Multiple genres of song were accompanied by numerous conventions for their social usages. Other activities at festivals included processional dancing, bullfights, horse races, cock and other bird fights, mountain climbing, ball tossing, and dragon boat races.' [179]//The Chinese material provides a general description of some Miao New Year's Festivals: 'The First Month. The first day of the first month is the beginning of the year. The Miao -I in this district would stick up paper money on the door of the house, which is also decorated with red peppers strung together with scented rice straw. Some of the Chung-chia people imitate the Chinese by asking calligraphers to pen symmetrical New Year verses for the door, [Page 99] 180 cont. and then hang out knots of scented rice straw, but no red peppers. These decorations are in expectation of a prosperous year.' [180]//'After having celebrated “The Big Year” on the thirtieth day of the twelfth month and having decorated the door on the New Year's day, the Hua Miao and the Ch'ing Miao would remain at home to rest without doing any work. The food for the New Year was prepared in advance on a lucky day (dragon and dog days are lucky), and it is not cooked again until another lucky day comes around. So on New Year's day there is no kitchen drudgery as only pre-cooked meals are eaten. The New Year's day being the first of the year, everything has to be auspicious and inhibitions are many. For instance, 1) no sewing is done by women at home; 2) nothing is taken into the house from outside; 3) no water is carried; 4) no knife is used; 5) no one is allowed to go barefooted and shoes must be worn; 6) no cursing is allowed; 7) no rapping on the wall is allowed; 8) the floor must not be swept; 9) no collection of debt is permitted. Besides, there are the proverbial “three days of liberty” when parents would allow their sons and daughters unrestrained freedom in the pursuit of recreation and happiness on the first, second and third days of the year. After this period the children once more submit themselves to parental restraint. On the first day of the year the old and young are clothed in new garments and have fun all day long. Only the Hsiung and Yang families among the Ch'ing Miao have the custom of worshipping ancestors in the evening. At the time of the sacrifice, the head of the family would spread a straw mat on the floor of the middle room or the side room and place on it incense and candles as well as three bowls of rice.
