In each bowl is pitched a piece of pork on a bamboo stick with three straw knots to represent the ancestors. In addition there are three bowls of beancurd and three pieces of tz'u-pa /glutinous rice balls/. They call out aloud to ask their ancestors to pass the New Year with them. Then the male members of the family begin to kowtow in the order of their age. After the paper money is completely burned, they gather up the things on the straw mat. The rice straw and the bamboo [Page 100] 181 cont. sticks are thrown into the temple of the Earth God outside the village.' [181]//'The New Year activities of the Chung-chia are slightly different from those of the Hua Miao and Ch'ing- Miao. On the first day of the year they also wear new clothes and decorate their doorway. At about seven o'clock in the morning they make sacrifices to their ancestors in the hall with several bowls of rice and meat while incense and candles are burned and fire-crackers are set off. The whole family, old and young, male and female, all participate in the ceremony as they perform the ritual of “three kneelings and nine kowtows.” After the sacrifice, the family settles down to a New Year feast in the hall, after which they stop working and laugh and joke all day. Their restrictions are similar to those of the Hua Miao and Ch'ing Miao. [...] On the second day of the New Year, the Hua Miao and the Ch'ing Miao would gather their family members after breakfast and with spades on their shoulders and wearing straw hats they would march off to their farms to do a little ploughing and digging, the idea being that this first “earth-removing” inaugurates a year's agricultural activities. With the Chung-chia, there is no definite day for the beginning of farm work, but it is generally around the tenth day of the first month. During the first three days of the year the Hua Miao, the Ch'ing Miao and the Chung-Chia would all stay home without going out for fear of meeting with unlucky events. On the fourth day the villages become astir with New Year visits between [Page 101] 182 cont. friends and relatives, and the younger generations pay respects to their elders (The New Year gifts for the children vary from ten to twenty cents.) When they exchange visits and greetings they bring with them a couple of home-made tz'u pa (each about 1 sheng of rice), candies and refreshments as gifts. The host and hostesses must entertain the visitors with tea and wine. The tenant farmers also present similar New Year gifts to their landlords, who in return would give them pieces of cloth or other household articles. As a rule such New Year greetings do not extend beyond the twelfth day though intimate relatives may offer theirs until the fifteenth. If a relative who has kept up these New Year visits throughout the past years fails to turn up, the family will be greatly offended. The Miao -I take the New Year greetings very seriously, and hence they should not be negleoted.' [182]//'The fifteenth day of the first month is the “Small New Year” with the Hua Miao and the Ch'ing Miao. That evening they put in front of the doorway a small table, on which are placed as sacrificial offerings a bowl of rice, a piece of meat and a cup of rice wine. Burning incense and lighting candles, they would kneel down and pray: “We pray to the Buddha tonight to guide us this year smoothly to wealth and prosperity.” After the prayer, the old and young, except the womenfolk, worship in turn. Then they sit down together for a feast in the hall. After dinner they have fun for the rest of the evening. The Chung-chia celebrate the “Small New Year” on the thirtieth day of the first month. Besides other delicacies at the table, every family makes tz'u-pa balls fried in oil, known as “eating oil balls.” They make sacrifices to their ancestors in great piety.' [183]//New Year's festivities were celebrated with games and other amusements as well as gift exchange: 'Among the Miao there is a swing game, which is quite interesting. On farm holidays when there are fairs or during the New Year festival, they put up frameworks for swings on a vacant lot. Each framework supports two swings, and every swing has four compartments, each fastened with ropes and a board. Each swing seats four men or women, going around with the wheel (Illus. 120). Men and women sing back and forth as they swing along (see chapter, “Folk Songs” /not translated/). The following song is about the origin of the swing: Songs and singing are as old as time, Found in all books everywhere. A son of a unicorn was born in the Sung dynasty. The young man with a clever mind sought a mate. He searched for a beauty but was ashamed of his own ugliness. He loved beauty but beauty was hard to meet. He asked someone for a plan. And was told to make a swing for people to enjoy. [Page 353] 236 Page 356] 239 cont. Shouting, he made known his invitation. A maid from the Sleeping Tiger Mountain, Came to ride on the eight-men swing. She was loved by all present. Soon, a go-between was found - Man and wife were joined together for a hundred years.' [184]//'Besides weddings and funerals, friends and relatives may exchange presents on New Year festivals or other happy occasions. Ordinarily when friends and relatives visit a family, the host, no matter whether he is rich or poor, must serve wine and food, if he did not the guests would view it as a sign of contempt. Intimate friends and relatives making the first call are not treated with goose or duck for fear that there might be quarrels between them later to hurt each other's feelings, as the beaks of the goose and duck are flat and large and therefore portend querulousness. If a chicken is used it must be cooked whole to see if the two eyes are completely closed. If one or two eyes are half open, then it is an evil portent.' [185]//Some authors claim sexual licence among young people as part of the festivities, but this has been contested: 'When the parents are unwilling to marry off a daughter, or nobody seeks her hand in marriage, or when the parents are unable or fail to make an engagement for a son, the marriageable person endeavors to win a mate. For this purpose he or she goes to the market place on the third day of the third moon, at tuan yang □ on the fifth day of the [Page [facing p. 36]] [Page 36] fifth moon, or at some other convenient time, or attends one of the Miao feasts or festivals, or joins those playing on the mountain-sides at New Year time. Either the boy or the girl can make the first advances. The methods are to look lovingly with the eyes, to squeeze hands and to speak loving words. This is inconvenient if there are many people about. A boy may take a girl's handkerchief or a girl take a boy's. Then the person who gets the handkerchief goes away and the other says, “That person has taken my handkerchief. Stay here and I will go after him (or her).” Then in a quiet secluded place they make love. They say loving words, squeeze each other's hands, and embrace. A very great evidence of love is when one spits and the other swallows the spittal. Copulation often follows after which a handkerchief or a ring may be given by the boy to the girl or vice versa and they make a vow such as, “If you do not marry me and marry another, you must take this engagement present and eat it and then I will make no trouble.” It is believed by the Ch'uan Miao men that copulation is one of the surest ways to a woman's affection.' [186]//Graham provides a translation of incantations performed on New Year's--the following examples are particularly relevant to Seshat. 'When the rice biscuits have been eaten, you must go and remove diseases and remove calamities and remove pains and remove quarrels and remove sins. You must leave them on the roads of the Lolo and the Chinese. You must add to the strength of your descendants so we can go and sow. You must add to their power so they can make clearings in the wilderness, so that your descendants will have food and clothing. Then you will have meat to eat and wine to drink and your descendants will sacrifice to three generations of female and male ancestors.' [187] 'My grandmother and my grandfather, to-day is the first day of the New Year. My three generations of female and male ancestors have come to drink New Year's wine. When you have drunk wine, you must lead your descendants forth to be scholars and civil officials and lead them to be military officials. After that you must look after your descendants so that they can raise many domestic animals. When you have drunk, you must make their descendants very numerous. You must cause the sons and grandsons to have food and drink. You must cause the descendants to accomplish so that they have meat to eat and wine to drink. Then they will first come and make offerings to you three generations of female and male ancestors so that you will all come and get (wine) to drink. When you have drunk and gone you must not nourish diseases (least they come and injure us). You must not nourish groans, you must not nourish quarrels, you must not nourish crimes, but let the descendants farm and get food and drink. They will first make offerings to the female and male ancestors of three generations so that they may come together and drink.' [188]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ not applicable ♥ It seems that the main festivities started on the thirtieth day of the twelfth month--the Big New Year [189]--to the fifteenth day of the first month--the Small New Year [190]. It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source. Thomas Cressy: Changed code from 'yearly' to 'not applicable' as no evidence is given for specialists
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ yearly ♥ It seems that the main festivities started on the thirtieth day of the twelfth month--the Big New Year [191]--to the fifteenth day of the first month--the Small New Year [192]. It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ not applicable ♥ It seems that the main festivities started on the thirtieth day of the twelfth month--the Big New Year [193]--to the fifteenth day of the first month--the Small New Year [194]. It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source. Thomas Cressy: Changed code from 'yearly' to 'not applicable' as no evidence is given for passive spectators, it seems everyone participated in celebrating the new year
♠ Duration ♣ 384 ♥ hours. 16 days. It seems that the main festivities started on the thirtieth day of the twelfth month--the Big New Year [195]--to the fifteenth day of the first month--the Small New Year [196]. It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 200,000 ♥ in absolute numbers Thomas Cressy: coded the polity's population figure in here
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ not applicable ♥
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ It does not seem that this ritual excluded any particular groups.
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ not applicable ♥ It does not seem that this ritual excluded any particular groups. Thomas Cressy: Changed code from 'whole polity' to 'not applicable' as no evidence is given for passive spectators, it seems everyone participated in celebrating the new year
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Besides weddings and funerals, friends and relatives may exchange presents on New Year festivals or other happy occasions. Ordinarily when friends and relatives visit a family, the host, no matter whether he is rich or poor, must serve wine and food, if he did not the guests would view it as a sign of contempt. Intimate friends and relatives making the first call are not treated with goose or duck for fear that there might be quarrels between them later to hurt each other's feelings, as the beaks of the goose and duck are flat and large and therefore portend querulousness. If a chicken is used it must be cooked whole to see if the two eyes are completely closed. If one or two eyes are half open, then it is an evil portent.' [197] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [198].
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [199].
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [200].
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [201].
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [202].
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [203].
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [204].
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [205].
♠ other ♣ present ♥ Gift giving
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ present ♥ 'Besides weddings and funerals, friends and relatives may exchange presents on New Year festivals or other happy occasions. Ordinarily when friends and relatives visit a family, the host, no matter whether he is rich or poor, must serve wine and food, if he did not the guests would view it as a sign of contempt. Intimate friends and relatives making the first call are not treated with goose or duck for fear that there might be quarrels between them later to hurt each other's feelings, as the beaks of the goose and duck are flat and large and therefore portend querulousness. If a chicken is used it must be cooked whole to see if the two eyes are completely closed. If one or two eyes are half open, then it is an evil portent.' [206] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ alcohol ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from the fact that alcohol was popular among the Hmong ('Both men and women smoke tobacco and drink wine.' [207]), as well as from the fact that this is not included in the Hmong's extensive list of New Year taboos: 'For instance, 1) no sewing is done by women at home; 2) nothing is taken into the house from outside; 3) no water is carried; 4) no knife is used; 5) no one is allowed to go barefooted and shoes must be worn; 6) no cursing is allowed; 7) no rapping on the wall is allowed; 8) the floor must not be swept; 9) no collection of debt is permitted.' [208] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from the fact that tobacco was popular among the Hmong ('Both men and women smoke tobacco and drink wine.' [209]), as well as from the fact that this is not included in the Hmong's extensive list of New Year taboos: 'For instance, 1) no sewing is done by women at home; 2) nothing is taken into the house from outside; 3) no water is carried; 4) no knife is used; 5) no one is allowed to go barefooted and shoes must be worn; 6) no cursing is allowed; 7) no rapping on the wall is allowed; 8) the floor must not be swept; 9) no collection of debt is permitted.' [210] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ sex ♣ {absent; present} ♥ Some authors claim sexual licence among young people as part of the festivities, but this has been contested: 'When the parents are unwilling to marry off a daughter, or nobody seeks her hand in marriage, or when the parents are unable or fail to make an engagement for a son, the marriageable person endeavors to win a mate. For this purpose he or she goes to the market place on the third day of the third moon, at tuan yang □ on the fifth day of the [Page [facing p. 36]] [Page 36] fifth moon, or at some other convenient time, or attends one of the Miao feasts or festivals, or joins those playing on the mountain-sides at New Year time. Either the boy or the girl can make the first advances. The methods are to look lovingly with the eyes, to squeeze hands and to speak loving words. This is inconvenient if there are many people about. A boy may take a girl's handkerchief or a girl take a boy's. Then the person who gets the handkerchief goes away and the other says, “That person has taken my handkerchief. Stay here and I will go after him (or her).” Then in a quiet secluded place they make love. They say loving words, squeeze each other's hands, and embrace. A very great evidence of love is when one spits and the other swallows the spittal. Copulation often follows after which a handkerchief or a ring may be given by the boy to the girl or vice versa and they make a vow such as, “If you do not marry me and marry another, you must take this engagement present and eat it and then I will make no trouble.” It is believed by the Ch'uan Miao men that copulation is one of the surest ways to a woman's affection.' [211] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ dancing ♣ present ♥ 'Other activities at festivals included processional dancing, bullfights, horse races, cock and other bird fights, mountain climbing, ball tossing, and dragon boat races.' [212] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ synchronous movement ♣ inferred present ♥ 'Other activities at festivals included processional dancing, bullfights, horse races, cock and other bird fights, mountain climbing, ball tossing, and dragon boat races.' [213] It seems reasonable to infer that 'processional dancing' included synchronous movement. It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ 'Among the Miao there is a swing game, which is quite interesting. On farm holidays when there are fairs or during the New Year festival, they put up frameworks for swings on a vacant lot. Each framework supports two swings, and every swing has four compartments, each fastened with ropes and a board. Each swing seats four men or women, going around with the wheel (Illus. 120). Men and women sing back and forth as they swing along (see chapter, “Folk Songs” /not translated/). The following song is about the origin of the swing: Songs and singing are as old as time, Found in all books everywhere. A son of a unicorn was born in the Sung dynasty. The young man with a clever mind sought a mate. He searched for a beauty but was ashamed of his own ugliness. He loved beauty but beauty was hard to meet. He asked someone for a plan. And was told to make a swing for people to enjoy. [Page 353] 236 Page 356] 239 cont. Shouting, he made known his invitation. A maid from the Sleeping Tiger Mountain, Came to ride on the eight-men swing. She was loved by all present. Soon, a go-between was found - Man and wife were joined together for a hundred years.' [214] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ entertainment ♣ present ♥ 'Other activities at festivals included processional dancing, bullfights, horse races, cock and other bird fights, mountain climbing, ball tossing, and dragon boat races.' [215] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ other ♣ ♥
Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [216].
♠ oath taking ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [217].
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Thomas Cressy: Changed code from 'present' to 'suspected unknown' and moved the quote to the 'obligations to each other's family' code, as no enemies or such a mindset is mentioned in the quote
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [218].
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ present ♥ Graham provides a translation of incantations performed on New Year's--the following is particularly relevant here. 'When the rice biscuits have been eaten, you must go and remove diseases and remove calamities and remove pains and remove quarrels and remove sins. You must leave them on the roads of the Lolo and the Chinese. You must add to the strength of your descendants so we can go and sow. You must add to their power so they can make clearings in the wilderness, so that your descendants will have food and clothing. Then you will have meat to eat and wine to drink and your descendants will sacrifice to three generations of female and male ancestors.' [219] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source. 'Besides weddings and funerals, friends and relatives may exchange presents on New Year festivals or other happy occasions. Ordinarily when friends and relatives visit a family, the host, no matter whether he is rich or poor, must serve wine and food, if he did not the guests would view it as a sign of contempt. Intimate friends and relatives making the first call are not treated with goose or duck for fear that there might be quarrels between them later to hurt each other's feelings, as the beaks of the goose and duck are flat and large and therefore portend querulousness. If a chicken is used it must be cooked whole to see if the two eyes are completely closed. If one or two eyes are half open, then it is an evil portent.' [220] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ other ♣ ♥
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [221].
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [222].
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ present ♥ "the younger generations pay respects to their elders (The New Year gifts for the children vary from ten to twenty cents" Thomas Cressy: Coded as present and pasted in a quote from the ritual description
♠ property/valuable items ♣ present ♥ 'Besides weddings and funerals, friends and relatives may exchange presents on New Year festivals or other happy occasions. Ordinarily when friends and relatives visit a family, the host, no matter whether he is rich or poor, must serve wine and food, if he did not the guests would view it as a sign of contempt. Intimate friends and relatives making the first call are not treated with goose or duck for fear that there might be quarrels between them later to hurt each other's feelings, as the beaks of the goose and duck are flat and large and therefore portend querulousness. If a chicken is used it must be cooked whole to see if the two eyes are completely closed. If one or two eyes are half open, then it is an evil portent.' [223] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ health costs ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by sources--which, however, date mostly to the twentieth century [224].
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ absent ♥ Though sources often refer to 'sacrifices' offered to the ancestors, it appears that these consist mostly of food; not only that, but it is specifically forbidden to use knives during the New Year holidays: 'For instance, 1) no sewing is done by women at home; 2) nothing is taken into the house from outside; 3) no water is carried; 4) no knife is used; 5) no one is allowed to go barefooted and shoes must be worn; 6) no cursing is allowed; 7) no rapping on the wall is allowed; 8) the floor must not be swept; 9) no collection of debt is permitted.' [225] It should be noted that this quote comes from a twentieth-century source.
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ The fact that our sources [226] do not mention something as sensational as human sacrifice suggests that it was not part of the festivities. It should be noted, however, that our sources date to the twentieth-century source.
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ absent ♥ The fact that our sources [227] do not mention something as sensational as human sacrifice suggests that it was not part of the festivities. It should be noted, however, that our sources date to the twentieth-century source.
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ The fact that our sources [228] do not mention something as sensational as human sacrifice suggests that it was not part of the festivities. It should be noted, however, that our sources date to the twentieth-century source.
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most widespread collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Sacrifice to Ancestors ♥ Hmong families regularly performed sacrifices to ancestors. '“Eating pigs” is called [kue□ mba□] in the Miao language, which means the “kuei”of pigs.” It is great sacrificial ceremony of the Miao, which honors the grandparents and the house kuei as well as the thunder kuei. From beginning to end it is performed for four days and is divided into 14 parts. For this occasion four pigs are prepared beforehand as well as a number of chin of waterbuffalo meat. The beef is cooked, and cut into slices, which are [Page 194] 131 cont. strung together in strings /skewers?/ of meat. There are 14 strings of seven slices each and 18 strings of nine slices each. The relatives by marriage, of a different surname, i. e. the mother's family and the wife's family, are invited to the function beforehand; and the mother's brother or the wife's maternal uncle are considered to belong to the lower generation for the ceremony.' [229]//'On the first night the first part is performed, which they call the opening of the affair. A large table is set up in the middle of the house. On it are placed five bowls of wine and five bowls of meat, one bowl of sour soup, one plate of cut-up beef, and a wooden bucket on which is placed a dried rice shoot. The sorcerer-priest's performance consists of first setting off firecrackers, next blowing a signal horn, and last beating a gong and drum, which is the end. The second, third, fourth, fifth, and sixth parts are performed on the second day. In the morning the second part is performed, which is the sacrifice to the grandparents and the house kuei. A small table is placed outside the main entrance. On it is placed an upper millstone upside down. A wooden bucket is placed on the stone, and on it are put a knife, two dried rice shoots, a few shoots of cow grass, and a sheaf of t'u-t'ou pai-yeh. There is also a tray with five cups of wine and a certain number of slices of cut-up beef. No beeswax is burned and the sorcerer-priest only utters an incantation and that is all. The third part is the sacrifice to the thunder kuei. It is very important not to eat any salt, because of the Miao superstition that the thunder kuei is very much afraid of salt. A large table is also set outside the fire entrance /? huo men/ and under it are put a hoe, rain clothes, and a plow. Moreover, on the table is put a tile, in the center of which are put a few small lumps of charcoal on which to burn the beeswax. Then [Page 195] they spread seven bowls each of wine, cooked rice, and waterbuffalo meat, a bowl of tea, and a bowl of sour soup. Altogether there are 23 bowls. In addition they put out two large bowls of water-buffalo meat, and place beside the table a live pig, whose four legs are tied up. On the outside wall of the house is hung a red rug. A spear piercing a piece of wood stands upside down on the ground beside the blanket. The sorcerer-priest sits down at the right side, holding a double-edged sword in the right hand, a sheaf of t'u-t'ou-pai-yeh in the left, and a bracelet. He utters an incantation, while attendants hold the wine pot and pass the wine, blow the signal horn, beat the gong and drum, and set off firecrackers, as in Illus. 59. First, seven strings [Page 196] 133 cont. of water-buffalo meat are offered, one string being offered each time, and ending with the seventh string. Then after the pig is offered to the kuei by the sorcerer-priest, the pig is sent to the kitchen to be killed and cooked. Then the cut-up meat of the pig and the heart, liver, intestines, and lungs are distributed in seven bowls and offered to the kuei.' [230]//'The fourth part is performed in the afternoon toward evening. A small table is set outside the entrance, on which are placed incense, rice, and li-shih (1) , and a pair of green candles as well as five cups of wine. The fifth part is performed at night after the first night watch is sounded. Two large tables are put together in the middle room. It is surrounded by a number of benches. On the tables are spread out 12 bowls of wine in two rows, six in a row, and 12 bowls of cooked rice in one long row. On top of each bowl of rice is a piece of pork and a pair of chopsticks stuck in it. There are also 12 bowls of meat, placed like the bowls of rice in a long row. In front of the bowls of meat are a bowl of tea and a bowl of sour soup. On one corner of the table is a wooden bucket, on which are two dried rice shoots and a double-edged sword. The sorcerer-priest and the members of the lower generation as well as the close relatives of the same clan sit down around the table. The sorcerer-priest performs his ritual, and the rest light firecrackers, blow the signal horn, and beat the drum, filling the hall with rumbling and roaring. The sixth part is performed after the second watch is sounded. A long door plank is set up outside the ground floor. On the plank are laid nine bowls of wine, nine bowls of meat, nine bowls of sweet wine, a bowl of sour soup, and a bowl of tea. On the right side is placed anupper millstone, on which is set up a bucket on which are put a dried rice shoot and a double-edged sword. The sorcerer-priest and three members of the lower generation are seated in a row, and behind them is hung a red rug. [Page 197] 133 cont. The sorcerer-priest carries out his performance by three times toasting and three times offering, five times toasting and five times offering, seven times toasting and seven times offering, until nine toasts and nine offerings have been made /sic/. The three members of the lower generation sit respectfully to keep the kuei company, as in Illus. 60. They sit until one of them has to go outside to relieve himself. Then the hostess gets out a cock, which is offered as a sacrifice by the sorcerer-priest, after which it is killed and cooked, and offered to the kuei.' [231]//'On the third day, the seventh, eighth, ninth, tenth, eleventh, and twelfth parts are performed. The seventh part is performed in the early morning. A long door plank is again set up, and on it are laid nine bowls each of wine and meat, a bowl of sour soup, and a bowl of tea, as well as incense, rice /uncooked/, and li-shih /paper horse/. A bow and arrow, a silver bracelet, and a bamboo splint are stuck on the table. There is also an upper millstone on which is a /Illus. 60 appears on p. 134/ 135 wooden bucket with two dry rice shoots and a double-edged sword on it. On the handle of the millstone is a bamboo-handled sieve, in which is found crosswise a wood plank, one end of which is cut into the shape of a fish with a small hole in it, tied with a piece of red cord. On the wood is carved the sign X. When everything is set out the sorcerer-priest starts to carry out his performance. The eighth part is performed with wine, cooked rice, and tea, seven bowls each, placed on the floor of the main house at the base of a pillar. The sorcerer-priest enacts his performance, uttering an incantation and making sacrifices to the ancestors. The Miao consider the base of the middle pillar the family altar where their ancestors rest. The ninth part is performed in the room to the left of the main house. A big fat pig is used, its four legs tied up and a wooden rod going through /between the legs/. The two ends of the rod are tied onto two wooden sticks. First, the sorcerer-priest offers the animal to the kuei. Then it is killed and cooked, and the meat packed into seven small bamboo baskets. The meat is then put into seven bowls, which are set up with seven bowls of [Page 198] 134 [Page 199] 135 cont. wine and cooked rice. In addition meat is sliced, and seven slices strung together to make one string. In all, seven strings of meat are put on a platter. The sorcerer-priest utters an incantation and divines with the chiao and sends off the kuei. This is the sacrifice to the kuei of the five grains.' [232]//'The tenth part is performed at noon, when two “Five-Flowr pillars (1) are set up in an open area, and to each pillar is tied a pig. The hind legs of the pigs are bound together with hemp ropes. This rope must have been made by members of the lower generation. Moreover, a cock is tied to a small wooden pillar near the ornate pillars by means of a fine hemp string threaded through the beak. The sorcerer-priest stands under the eaves of the house, wearing a cap and long gown and holding in his hand a tree branch. The host wears a ceremonial hat and a red rug thrown over his body. He first picks up a bench and places it against one of the Five-Flower pillars, holding in his left hand a double-edged sword and a bamboo splint and flourishing the latter as if he were driving the pigs away. The sorcerer-priest utters an incantation to send the pigs away, and after the incense and the paper are burned, the various members of the lower generation come out grasping weapons as in Illus. 61. They bow three times facing the interior of the house and three times facing the outside. Then they kill the pigs and the chicken. The eleventh part is performed in front of the main house. A bamboo mat is spread on the ground and on it are placed the caps and clothes of the members of the lower generation. Behind the mat there is a bench, on which are placed a bowl of wine and a piece of water-buffalo meat. The sorcerer-priest stands outside the entrance, wearing a wide rain hat on his head and carrying a bamboo cage on his back, in which are clothes and other articles. [Page 200] 136 [Page 201] 135 cont Wielding a wooden rod, he utters an incantation, telling of the source of the kuei of pigs. After the incantation he goes directly into the house and partakes of the wine and meat on the bench.' [233]//'The twelfth part is performed late at night or in the fourth or fifth watch. The long door boards are put up as a table. /Illus. 61 appears on p. 136/ 137 The two paris of pigs from the Five-Flower pillars, which have been killed, cut up, and washed clean, are put on the table with the heads of the pigs facing the interior of the house. On the table are further laid out wine, meat, and sweet wine, nine bowls each, as well as a bowl of sour soup and a bowl of tea. There are also 12 bowls of cooked rice, on each of which is placed a string of lean and fat pork. The upper millstone, incense, rice /uncooked/ and li-shih are also there. There is no blowing and beating of instruments, only the sorcerer-priest's soft-voiced, gentle petition. On the fourth day the thirteenth and the fourteenth parts are performed. The thirteenth takes place when the cock crows in the fifth watch. A member of the lower generation with a felt rug thrown over his body and a straw hat on his head holds an ox horn containing wine in his left hand and a knife in his right hand, as well as grasping a string of seven slices of pork. He walks to a river bank or a well. He empties the wine from the horn and puts in clear water. While returning, he eats the seven slices of meat. Arriving at the gate, he imitates the crowing of the cock. After entering the house he sits down. On the table is laid a tray on which are set three cups of wine and three slices of meat. Under the tray is a jar, into which the water is emptied from the horn. The sorcerer-priest strikes the drum and utters an incantation. After the incantation the water carrier runs out the door, while the host throws ashes from used firewood on his body. The fourteenth part is to send the kuei away and is performed in the early morning. The pigs' heads are cooked and cut into small slices or chunks, and are distributed in three trays, on each of which are placed three cups of wine. One tray is put at the foot of the middle pillar in the main house; one tray is placed on the floor of the front-half side room; and one [Page 202] 137 cont. tray is put beside the entrance. The incantation, uttered by the sorcerer-priest sends off the kuei.' [234]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ suspected unknown ♥ It is unclear from the reviewed ethnography how often this sacrifice was performed.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ suspected unknown ♥ It is unclear from the reviewed ethnography how often this sacrifice was performed.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ not applicable ♥ It is unclear from the reviewed ethnography how often this sacrifice was performed.
♠ Duration ♣ 96 ♥ hours. 'From beginning to end it is performed for four days and is divided into 14 parts.' [235] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ suspected unknown ♥ in absolute numbers
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ elites ♥ shamans
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ It appears that all Hmong had to perform this ceremony.
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ not applicable ♥ It appears that all Hmong had to perform this ceremony. Thomas Cressy: As all had to perform this, there is no evidence of passive spectators, so I changed 'whole polity' to 'not applicable'

Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by our source [245]--which, however, dates to the twentieth century. The host did provide food and drink to his guests, but it does not appear that these were in any notably large quantities.
♠ alcohol ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by our source [246]--which, however, dates to the twentieth century. The host did provide food and drink to his guests, but it does not appear that these were in any notably large quantities.

♠ entertainment ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by our source [252]--which, however, dates to the twentieth century. The source does mention firecrackers and music, but, given the context, it seems likely that these were not seen by participants as 'entertainment'.

[257] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.

♠ animal sacrifice ♣ present ♥ 'Then after the pig is offered to the kuei by the sorcerer-priest, the pig is sent to the kitchen to be killed and cooked. Then the cut-up meat of the pig and the heart, liver, intestines, and lungs are distributed in seven bowls and offered to the kuei.' [262] First, the sorcerer-priest offers the animal to the kuei. Then it is killed and cooked, and the meat packed into seven small bamboo baskets. The meat is then put into seven bowls, which are set up with seven bowls of wine and cooked rice. In addition meat is sliced, and seven slices strung together to make one string. In all, seven strings of meat are put on a platter. The sorcerer-priest utters an incantation and divines with the chiao and sends off the kuei. This is the sacrifice to the kuei of the five grains.' [263] 'Then they kill the pigs and the chicken.' [264] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ The creatures sacrificed were all animals. Then the cut-up meat of the pig and the heart, liver, intestines, and lungs are distributed in seven bowls and offered to the kuei.' [265] First, the sorcerer-priest offers the animal to the kuei. Then it is killed and cooked, and the meat packed into seven small bamboo baskets. The meat is then put into seven bowls, which are set up with seven bowls of wine and cooked rice. In addition meat is sliced, and seven slices strung together to make one string. In all, seven strings of meat are put on a platter. The sorcerer-priest utters an incantation and divines with the chiao and sends off the kuei. This is the sacrifice to the kuei of the five grains.' [266] 'Then they kill the pigs and the chicken.' [267] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.

In addition meat is sliced, and seven slices strung together to make one string. In all, seven strings of meat are put on a platter. The sorcerer-priest utters an incantation and divines with the chiao and sends off the kuei. This is the sacrifice to the kuei of the five grains.' [269] 'Then they kill the pigs and the chicken.' ♠ other ♣ ♥

Most frequent collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ healing rituals ♥ There are many ethnographic accounts of different types of Hmong healing rituals. The following is particularly detailed. 'When a Miao becomes ill and taking medicine does not make him better, then he must make a vow to “ta chia hsien” /lit. “beat the family ancestors”/, which in the Miao language is called [pa□ mba□ □ior□], which means “beating Miao pigs.” It may be performed during the illness or after the recovery. Before the event takes place, the host must serve notice to members of the mother's brother's family, inviting them to send seven members of the maternal uncle's family (six men and a woman) to be guests. If that family does not have so many people, the maternal uncle may ask other people to make up the number. But the persons invited should not have the same surname as the host. No day needs to be selected as lucky, but the following days must be avoided: if a child is born in the family, it is necessary to wait one month before the ceremony is performed; the birth of kittens also necessitates one month's separation; the birth of pigs, goats, cows, horses, and dogs causes a postponement of 12 days; the hatching of chicks, ducklings, and goslings, three days; a funeral in the family or when the head of the family has witnessed a funeral of another family, 12 days. If the notice should arrive before the time of expiration of any of the above periods, the maternal uncle's family may refuse such an invitation. If the host because he seeks an immediate recovery from a sickness cannot wait any longer, he may invite other guests, but they may not have the same surname as he. The Ta Chia Hsien ceremony is divided into four parts, requiring a whole day from morning till night. There are altogether eight kuei invited: [na□ n□ t□ te□], n□ ma□ bu□ □ie□], tso□ te□ tso□ tie□], [bu□ ie□ tsei□ n□] (it is said that these four are the ordinary names for the kuei of [Page 203] 138 cont. the ancestors). □, (this is the oldest ancestral kuei); [tso□ me□ t□ □io□], [iso□ to□ t□ lie□], (these are the kuei names of the seven invited guests). The place is beside the fire pit inside the house. The Miao sorcerer-priest sits on a low stool behind the fire pit, facing the entrance. In front of him is a bamboo tube and a bowl of wax. In front of the fire pit is set up a square table, on which are placed ten square pieces of fancy /flower/ paper divided in two rows. On each square of paper in the back row is placed a bowl of wine, and behind the back row are stuck up four paper kuei. In the two far corners of the table are stuck up two paper flags. Two chickens are tied to the legs of the table with fine cord through their beaks. Two pigs with their feet tied up with rope are placed in front of the chickens, heads facing the stove. To the right of the Miao sorcerer-priest, on the floor, there is a bamboo mat, on which is a /cooked/ rice bucket /Illus. 62 appears here/ 139 with the lid off, and a bit in front is a jar, in which is put a piece of fancy paper with a bowl of wine on it. In front of the mat to the right of the fire pit is a winnowing basket. Above it three pieces of bamboo form a semicircular top, on the outside of which paper is pasted, and then cloth. Inside are stuck three paper kuei, in the middle four pieces of fancy paper, and on each of the two pieces of paper in the rear is placed a bowl of wine, see Illus. 62.' [274]//'For the first part, which concerns inviting the shen, the Miao sorcerer sits on the stool, without using any of his magic implements, and only uttering an incantation, whose general purport is as follows: "All you older and younger relatives of the host! The host has recently run into bad luck. When he walked on the road, he saw strange happenings among the grass and trees. When he ate, there were inexplicable fragments and pieces of a broken saucepan in his rice. When the host looked quickly, then he saw these strange phenomena. The (here the name of the ancestral kuei of the family is mentioned) kuei, wanting food to eat, first came and did these things, then made the host fall sick. The host, not getting well, made a vow, and after this, his sickness left him. [Page 204] 139 cont. The vow has extricated him from the clutches of the kuei, and the sickness has not come back, but is forever uprooted. The host has saved money and bought a fat pig from the market as well as paper money. Having waited for the passing of the days to be avoided, then he comes to the sacrifice to the kuei. Sorcerer-priests are very few in this world, and he came to my home to invoke my help. So, here I am. I ask all the kuei to come here. I burn a bowl of beeswax. The bamboo tube and the bell are beside the fire pit. The two winnowing baskets filled with meat, the gold and silver cans, the gold and silver chair cushions, all are set at the sides of the pit. The table for the sacrifice to the kuei, the paper money for the redemption of the soul, the fancy /flowr/ bowl to hold the wine, the fat pigs, big and small, two large chickens-these [Page 205] 139 cont. are all placed beside the table. We request the kuei to come to take them. And after taking them, please eat quickly." (He utters the name of the ancestral kuei of the family.)' [275]//'The second part consists of beating the bamboo tube. While beating the bamboo tube, the Miao sorcerer utters an incantation, generally describing many supernatural phenomena, such as the mischievous behavior of the 12 large trees; strange happenings after eating fish, meat, bamboo shoots, and smoking tobacco; strange happenings with the water at the time of using water, in a bath or sitting in a boat; strange happenings with clothes; strange happenings with ants and snails; with wooden rods and bamboo poles, etc. The third part is the handing over of the animals. After the incantation for the second part is finished, there is a short respite. The Miao sorcerer then picks up the bamboo tube and the bowl of beeswax is moved onto the table. Afterward he asks a man and a woman from among the seven guests from the maternal uncle's family to sit opposite each other, the man inside next to the bamboo mat facing outward, the woman outside next to the winnowing basket facing inward. The rest of the five men sit at the table on a bench next to the fire pit, without making a movement. The Miao sorcerer, holding a bamboo chiao in his right hand and ringing the hand bell with his left, begins once more to utter an incantation:140 “The wine for ta chia hsien is now ready. There are altogether seven empty wine bowls, two beside the fire pit and five beside the entrance. Please come and take them! After taking them, please do not drink right away. As for the pigs and chickens, if not sent they will not arrive. Once we send them they will arrive. I invoke my patron saint's soldiers and horses; I order my own 1,000 men and 10,000 horses to help deliver the large pig, to help send the small pig and the two chickens. The chickens are sent to the coop, the small pig is sent to the pig sty, and the large pig is sent to the tower.”' [276]//'At this point the sorcerer-priest makes the gesture of forcibly sending off the pig. While sending off the pig he says three phrases of a magic formula in a low tone. The bystanders can only see his lips moving but cannot hear anything. According to the Miao sorcerer, at the time his teacher taught him this formula, he repeatedly warned him that after that day he must not teach it to any insincere disciple and must not teach them indiscriminatingly to anyone, or else, the person who teaches it may lose his life or his methods would not be effective. After having finished the three phrases of the magic formula to send off the pig, once more in a loud voice he intones: “Helpers take the wooden rod and hit the pig in the chest and kill it. Roast it with fire and wash it with water! Do it quickly! The kuei have been waiting here for fully half a day already.” After the incantation is over, the host and the helpers kill the animal with the rod and carry it inside the house. They roast it over the fire, then wash it with water, lay bare the stomach, and cut the pig into two halves: one half is taken by the host, with one leg cut off for the sorcerer-priest, and the other half is received by the seven guests. The other pig is similarly distributed, but after the host's share is put aside, the guests' share is cut into small chunks, and seven bowls are filled with meat. Two bowls are placed on fancy paper in the winnowing basket, and five bowls, on fancy paper at the table. Then, a few other chunks of meat are put into a tin can on the mat. After the meat has been set up, each person returns to his original seat. The fourth part is to send the kuei away. The sorcerer-priest, ringing the hand bell with his left hand and holding the chiao with his right hand, utters an incantation to the following effect: “The pork has been cooked in the saucepan. Seven fine bowls of meat and seven fine bowls of wien have been placed beside the stove. Another ten bowls of meat have been put beside the entrance. This sorcerer-priest takes this wine and meat and offers them to the ancestral kuei. So, please receive them.”' [277] 'After the incantation, divination with chiao is performed for every member of the family. Next, divination is performed to see whether the kuei have gone. If the kuei have gone, then the guests taste a little of the pork, and then return home, carrying with them their share of the meat. At this time the sorcerer-priest and the host both cannot eat the pork. The sorcerer-priest has to collect all the paper kuei, paper flags, and paper money, and burn them up on the main road. Meanwhile, the host kills the two chickens and cooks them, and waits for the sorcerer-priest to come back so that they may eat it together.' [278]

Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ present ♥ The sorcerer-priest has to collect all the paper kuei, paper flags, and paper money, and burn them up on the main road. Meanwhile, the host kills the two chickens and cooks them, and waits for the sorcerer-priest to come back so that they may eat it together.' [308]
♠ property/valuable items ♣ present ♥ The ethnography mentions the presentation of paper [309].

♠ animal sacrifice ♣ present ♥ Pigs and smaller animals were sacrificed [311].
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by our main source [312]--which, however, dates to the twentieth century. (i.e. an individual who is not considered part of the group performing the ritual)
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by our main source [313]--which, however, dates to the twentieth century. (i.e. an individual who is considered part of the group performing the ritual)
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by our main source [314]--which, however, dates to the twentieth century. (e.g. sacrificing the first-born son)
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most euphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Ox Sacrifice ♥ Oxen were sacrificed after the termination of serious illness or childlessness. 'Bludgeoning the Ox is called in the Miao language /kueηy □ie□/, meaning the “kuei of the water buffalo,” and is the greatest of all Miao sacrificial rites. When a Miao is seriously ill and it is found through divination that the kuei of the water buffalo is causing the trouble, or when a person is childless by middle age and it is divined that the water buffalo kuei is preventing the Queen of the Nether World at South Heaven Gate to send forth a child, a Miao sorcerer is invited to the house to burn beeswax, to beat gong and drum, and to make a great vow to bludgeon an ox. After the vow is made, if the sickness has been cured or the son sought is born, it is then believed that the kuei of the ox has bestowed it. Then, it becomes necessary to make preparations to fulfil the vow to bludgeon an ox. The selection of the water buffalo to buy is most important. It is necessary to select a water buffalo with the four quarters having four spirals /?/ and the ears, eyes, mouth, nose, horns, and hoofs must be right and complete. Sometimes it is very difficult to buy such an animal, and when found, the price is always prohibitive. If the host succeeds in buying a water buffalo at the market, then someone is sent home ahead to carry the news, so that the members of the family can prepare gongs and drums to meet the ox halfway. When the ox is led into the house, the gongs and drums stop, and [Page 208] 141 cont. incense and paper are burned. They watch the stance of the animal to divine good and bad luck. If the water buffalo, on entering the house, lifts his feet to advance, with its head facing the incense censer, and glances at the ancestral shrine, then it portends good luck. If the water buffalo is stubborn and refuses to move forward or even tries to back out as if frightened, then it portends bad luck. After the water buffalo has been bought, a Miao sorcerer is asked to come to the house to present the ox to the kuei, and also to beseech the kuei. After this presentation, the family has to wait for the first frost after the autumn harvest to make the sacrifice. When the date is decided it is never changed or postponed.' [315]//'After the autumn harvest has been completed and the first frost has arrived, an auspicious day is chosen to sacrifice to the kuei. Half a month before, four paternal male cousins are asked to go separately to where the relatives live to notify them. The most important relatives are the families of the hosts mother's brother and the wife's maternal uncle, who are said to be the “leg-bearing relatives.” They are so-called because after sacrificing to the kuei, one leg of the buffalo is given to the maternal uncle's relatives. A buffalo is divided into four legs. The first belongs to the /host's/ mother's brother, the second to the wife's maternal uncle, and the third and fourth are sent to other close relatives. The “leg-bearing relatives on receiving the notification presents the messenger with a strip of red cloth as an expression of gratitude. Moreover, within the 12 days before the sacrifice, one must avoid seeing unclean things, such as a dead cat, a dead dog, or a dead person. If this avoidance is violated, then the person may not be in the company of the buffalo kuei. The “leg-bearing” relatives often go together with the clan brothers /of the host/, making up a number of at least ten or more men up to as many as 60 or 70. Also invited are musicians, trumpeteers /?/, and drummers, to go in formation. Wealthy families imitate the old customs of the former Manchu dynasty, displaying official insignia, playing fine music, and beating gongs and carrying parasols. The maternal uncle's family entitled to the first leg [Page 209] 141 cont. also must provide a sharp spear and a large creeper. The spear is used to stab the ox, and the creeper, to tie its head.' [316]//'The Bludgeoning the Ox sacrifice to the kuei is the most lavish affair of the Miao. In addition to the water buffalo, the host also has to buy a common ox, two pigs, two chickens, and incense and paper, firecrackers, sweet wine, and sour fish. The relatives all have to send gifts. Formerly the Miao Bludgeoning-the-Buffalo sacrifice to the kuei lasted for five days, but now it lasts only three days. The first day is to honor the guests. That morning the “leg-bearing” relatives arrive in formation. As they approach the host's house they set, off firecrackers and play music. The host comes out to welcome them by burning incense and paper before them and kowtowing three times. The Miao consider that the water buffalo kuei comes with the mother's brother. By the time the lamps are lit in the evening, most of the guests invited have arrived; and after supper men and women guests begin to sing songs (see the chapter “Folk Songs,” songs Nos. 29 and 30, “Eating Ox Song,” and songs 33, 34, and 35, called “Beating the Flower Drum Song” /not translated/) and dance drum dances. [...] The host first starts the drumming, followed by the “leg-bearing” relatives, then by other guests according to the degree of relationship with the host, and last by the helpers. At the same time the sorcerer-priest begins his performance, using two large tables put together in the main house to make a long table, on which are then spread rice husks, on which are placed wine bowls, meat bowls, an iron tripod holding a tin can, and an upper millstone. The table is surrounded on all four sides with a number of plank benches. The sorcerer-priest and four “leg-bearing” relatives properly dressed in full dress, and sometimes they wear spirit robes /shen p'ao/. The sorcerer-priest sits in the middle and the four men sit next. Those who blow trumpets and beat drums and gongs sit below. The sorcerer-priest, ringing a hand bell with his right hand and holding a chiao-tzu in his left hand, begins uttering an incantation. [Page 210] 142 cont. After each passage the musicians play their instruments a while. When the sorcerer-priest has occasion to stand up, the four “leg-bearing” men who accompanied the kuei also stand up; when the sorcerer-priest sits down, the “leg-bearing” men also sit down; when he presents wine, they must also do so. From first to last it is done nine times until late at night.' [317]//'In the morning of the second day the sorcerer-priest orders the helpers to go outside the village to choose an open area to erect Five-Flower pillars. After the pillars are erected they make bamboo rings with bamboo strips and put them around the pillars. A piece of hemp rope is used to tie the nose of the ox to the bamboo ring. The creeper brought by the “leg-bearing” relatives are used to bind up the horns so that the animal cannot hurt anyone with the horns, see Illus. 63. After the arrangements have been finished, the sorcerer-priest is asked to make an inspection, and if he finds everything satisfactorily arranged, then they can proceed. The host then changes into new clothes, and offers wine and meat as sacrifices to the kuei, burns incense and paper, and kneels three times and kowtows nine times facing the ox. At the same time the sorcerer-priest utters an incantation, telling the origin of the ox kuei. After the incantation is finished, the mother's brother takes hold of the spear and acts as if he were chasing the ox to stab it. The spear is then taken by a young man to do the actual stabbing of the animal. At the same time the din from the drums and gongs rends the air and the ox runs around the Five-Flower pillars, /Illus. 63 appears between pp. 142 and 143./ 143 with the man pursuing and repeatedly stabbing, until the animal is dazed and falls to the ground. They note the direction in which the head falls to decide whether the sign is auspicious or not. If the head faces toward the host's house, it is a good omen; if the head faces away, then it is a bad omen. After the animal has been stabbed to death, then the meat is divided up. The head and heart, liver, entrails, and bowels go to the host to be used to sacrifice to the kuei. The left and right hind legs go to the “first- and second-leg-bearing” relatives, [Page 211] between pp. 142 and 143. [Page 212] 143 cont. and the left and right forelegs to the “third- and fourth-leg-bearing” relatives. The breast portion goes to the sorcerer-priest.' [318]//'In the morning of the third day, the sorcerer-priest once more performs his ritual in the main house. At the same time the guests are leaving. Besides the “leg-bearing” relatives, who each receives a leg, the other friends and relatives all get portions of the beef from six liang to half a chin, sometimes as much as two chin, depending upon the degree of intimacy they have with the host.' [319]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ yearly ♥ It seems reasonable that a single shaman would perform this ritual at least once a year. 'When a Miao is seriously ill and it is found through divination that the kuei of the water buffalo is causing the trouble, or when a person is childless by middle age and it is divined that the water buffalo kuei is preventing the Queen of the Nether World at South Heaven Gate to send forth a child, a Miao sorcerer is invited to the house to burn beeswax, to beat gong and drum, and to make a great vow to bludgeon an ox. After the vow is made, if the sickness has been cured or the son sought is born, it is then believed that the kuei of the ox has bestowed it. Then, it becomes necessary to make preparations to fulfil the vow to bludgeon an ox. [...] After this presentation, the family has to wait for the first frost after the autumn harvest to make the sacrifice. When the date is decided it is never changed or postponed.' [320] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ once per generation ♥ We have assumed that participants and audience members experienced these festivities more often than once in a lifetime, but less often than annually. 'When a Miao is seriously ill and it is found through divination that the kuei of the water buffalo is causing the trouble, or when a person is childless by middle age and it is divined that the water buffalo kuei is preventing the Queen of the Nether World at South Heaven Gate to send forth a child, a Miao sorcerer is invited to the house to burn beeswax, to beat gong and drum, and to make a great vow to bludgeon an ox. After the vow is made, if the sickness has been cured or the son sought is born, it is then believed that the kuei of the ox has bestowed it. Then, it becomes necessary to make preparations to fulfil the vow to bludgeon an ox.' [321] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ once per generation ♥ We have assumed that participants and audience members experienced these festivities more often than once in a lifetime, but less often than annually. 'When a Miao is seriously ill and it is found through divination that the kuei of the water buffalo is causing the trouble, or when a person is childless by middle age and it is divined that the water buffalo kuei is preventing the Queen of the Nether World at South Heaven Gate to send forth a child, a Miao sorcerer is invited to the house to burn beeswax, to beat gong and drum, and to make a great vow to bludgeon an ox. After the vow is made, if the sickness has been cured or the son sought is born, it is then believed that the kuei of the ox has bestowed it. Then, it becomes necessary to make preparations to fulfil the vow to bludgeon an ox.' [322] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ Duration ♣ 120 ♥ hours. 5 days. ‘Formerly the Miao Bludgeoning-the-Buffalo sacrifice to the kuei lasted for five days, but now it lasts only three days.’ [323] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ suspected unknown ♥ in absolute numbers
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ elites ♥ A 'sorcerer-priest' was needed for this ritual [324]. NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ The following suggests that any Hmong, in theory, could perform this ritual. 'When a Miao is seriously ill and it is found through divination that the kuei of the water buffalo is causing the trouble, or when a person is childless by middle age and it is divined that the water buffalo kuei is preventing the Queen of the Nether World at South Heaven Gate to send forth a child, a Miao sorcerer is invited to the house to burn beeswax, to beat gong and drum, and to make a great vow to bludgeon an ox. After the vow is made, if the sickness has been cured or the son sought is born, it is then believed that the kuei of the ox has bestowed it. Then, it becomes necessary to make preparations to fulfil the vow to bludgeon an ox.' [325] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ The following suggests that any Hmong, in theory, could observe this ritual. 'When a Miao is seriously ill and it is found through divination that the kuei of the water buffalo is causing the trouble, or when a person is childless by middle age and it is divined that the water buffalo kuei is preventing the Queen of the Nether World at South Heaven Gate to send forth a child, a Miao sorcerer is invited to the house to burn beeswax, to beat gong and drum, and to make a great vow to bludgeon an ox. After the vow is made, if the sickness has been cured or the son sought is born, it is then believed that the kuei of the ox has bestowed it. Then, it becomes necessary to make preparations to fulfil the vow to bludgeon an ox.' [326] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ 'After the animal has been stabbed to death, then the meat is divided up. The head and heart, liver, entrails, and bowels go to the host to be used to sacrifice to the kuei. The left and right hind legs go to the “first- and second-leg-bearing” relatives, and the left and right forelegs to the “third- and fourth-leg-bearing” relatives. The breast portion goes to the sorcerer-priest.' [327] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by the source [328]. However, it is worth noting that this source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ fear ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by the source [329]. However, it is worth noting that this source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ humiliation ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by the source [330]. However, it is worth noting that this source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ disgust ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by the source [331]. However, it is worth noting that this source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by the source [332]. However, it is worth noting that this source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ pain ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by the source [333]. However, it is worth noting that this source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ mutilation ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by the source [334]. However, it is worth noting that this source dates to the twentieth century.

Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ present ♥ 'After the animal has been stabbed to death, then the meat is divided up. The head and heart, liver, entrails, and bowels go to the host to be used to sacrifice to the kuei. The left and right hind legs go to the “first- and second-leg-bearing” relatives, and the left and right forelegs to the “third- and fourth-leg-bearing” relatives. The breast portion goes to the sorcerer-priest.' [336] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ alcohol ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Though food was consumed [337], it is not clear whether alcohol was drunk also.
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by the source [338]. However, it is worth noting that this source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ sex ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by the source [339]. However, it is worth noting that this source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ dancing ♣ present ♥ 'By the time the lamps are lit in the evening, most of the guests invited have arrived; and after supper men and women guests begin to sing songs (see the chapter “Folk Songs,” songs Nos. 29 and 30, “Eating Ox Song,” and songs 33, 34, and 35, called “Beating the Flower Drum Song” /not translated/) and dance drum dances.' [340] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ synchronous movement ♣ suspected unknown ♥ 'By the time the lamps are lit in the evening, most of the guests invited have arrived; and after supper men and women guests begin to sing songs (see the chapter “Folk Songs,” songs Nos. 29 and 30, “Eating Ox Song,” and songs 33, 34, and 35, called “Beating the Flower Drum Song” /not translated/) and dance drum dances.' [341] It is not clear whether these dances were in any way synchronous.
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ 'By the time the lamps are lit in the evening, most of the guests invited have arrived; and after supper men and women guests begin to sing songs (see the chapter “Folk Songs,” songs Nos. 29 and 30, “Eating Ox Song,” and songs 33, 34, and 35, called “Beating the Flower Drum Song” /not translated/) and dance drum dances.' [342] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ entertainment ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Drum dances and music were performed after the sacrifice (see above). Thomas Cressy: Changed from 'present' to 'suspected unknown', due to this music being sacrificial music rather than entertainment music

Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ property/valuable items ♣ present ♥ 'The selection of the water buffalo to buy is most important. It is necessary to select a water buffalo with the four quarters having four spirals /?/ and the ears, eyes, mouth, nose, horns, and hoofs must be right and complete. Sometimes it is very difficult to buy such an animal, and when found, the price is always prohibitive.' [350] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ health costs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by the source [351]. However, it is worth noting that this source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ present ♥ 'After the incantation is finished, the mother's brother takes hold of the spear and acts as if he were chasing the ox to stab it. The spear is then taken by a young man to do the actual stabbing of the animal. At the same time the din from the drums and gongs rends the air and the ox runs around the Five-Flower pillars, /Illus. 63 appears between pp. 142 and 143./ 143 with the man pursuing and repeatedly stabbing, until the animal is dazed and falls to the ground.' [352] NOTE: Our main source dates to the twentieth century.
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ The creature sacrificed was an ox. The spear is then taken by a young man to do the actual stabbing of the animal. At the same time the din from the drums and gongs rends the air and the ox runs around the Five-Flower pillars, /Illus. 63 appears between pp. 142 and 143./ 143 with the man pursuing and repeatedly stabbing, until the animal is dazed and falls to the ground.'
